to Mesoproterozoic intracratonic..., Gondwana Research (2013), http://dx
approximately 1420 Ma. The zircon grains formed between 1.40 and
1.46 Ga had Hf model ages (TDMs) from 2.38 to 1.59 Ga, and ?Hf values
from ?12.97 to 7.43. The most abundant population had a TDM of
approximately 2.0 Ga and ?Hf values of between ?4.18 and ?1.62
(Fig. 8). Thus, the youngest zircon population (U–Pb ages) contains juve-
nile and re-melted zircon crystals, that were formed ca. 1.5 Ga, 1.7–
1.8 Ga, 2.1–2.2 Ga or during the Archean Era (4.0–2.5 Ga).

5.1.2. Sandstone detrital zircon grains
The Tombador Fm. lower section contains only inherited zircons,

with ages that fall within three well-defined clusters. These clusters rep-
resent the basement rocks of the Chapada Diamantina (Barbosa and
Sabaté, 2004) and include the following: Paleoarchean (3.6–3.2 Ga),
Neoarchean (3.2–2.8 Ga) and Paleoproterozoic (2.5–1.6 Ga; Fig. 7).
Based on the age ranges observed in the detrital zircons, the most likely
source regions include the Gavião Block and the Itabuna–Salvador–
Curaçá Belt of the São Francisco Craton basement.

In the upper section of the Tombador Fm., the pattern of inheritance
changes as there is an influx of Mesoproterozoic-aged zircons. The
upper Tombador Fm. detrital zircons yielded varying proportions of
basement (older than 1.8 Ga) and Mesoproterozoic zircon grains
(Fig. 7). This distribution pattern is very similar to the crystal-tuff zircon
age distribution. The ca. 1.7 and 1.5 Ga detrital zircon grains represent
recycling of the ES lower sections, the Rio dos Remédios (ca. 1.7 Ga)
and the Paraguaçú groups (ca. 1.5 Ga; see discussion Section 5.3). The
youngest zircon grains from the upper Tombador Fm. crystal-tuff and
sandstone samples (P1 and P2) were between 1.4 and 1.45 Ga (Figs. 6
and 7).

The Tombador Fm. unconformably overlies the Açuruá Fm. (i.e., the
top of the Paraguaçú Group). The low-angle unconformity that sepa-
rates these formations and the well-documented paleocurrent changes
from eastward in the Açuruá Fm. to westward in the Tombador Fm.
(Pedreira, 1994; Pedreira and De Waele, 2008) indicate a tectonic tilt
of the Congo–São Francisco Craton from anomalous topography east
of Chapada Diamantina. The addition of Mesoproterozoic zircon grains
in the upper Tombador Fm. detrital zircon assemblage (relative to the
lower Tombador Fm.) support the source area change (Fig. 7). Based
on the westward sediment transport of the Tombador Fm. (Pedreira,
1994; Pedreira and De Waele, 2008), we suggest that the volcanic
source area was located east of the Chapada Diamantina, most likely
in the Congo Craton.

An important regional intraplate extensional regime was established
at ca. 1375 Ma in the Congo Craton. This extensional regime was associ-
ated with voluminous S- and A-type granitoids and mafic–ultramafic
complexes that were found in the Karagwe–Ankolian Belt (KAB) east
of the Congo Craton (Tack et al., 2010; Fernandez-Alonso et al., 2012,
and references therein) and in the Kunene complexes and related
granites west of the Congo Craton (Ernst et al., 2013b, and references
therein). Both events may have triggered the Congo–São Francisco
paleoplate tilt and volcanism.

The syn-sedimentary volcanism at ca. 1.42 Ga has not been recorded
in the ES units. However, Chemale et al. (2012) determined the ca.
1.4 Ga detrital zircon ages in the Conselheiro Mata Group in the South-
ern Espinhaço range. This group is coeval with the Cabloco Fm., which
overlies the Tombador Fm (see discussion Section 5.3 and Fig. 9).

5.2. The source for the Tombador and Sopa–Brumadinho Formation zircon
crystals

The Tombador and Sopa–Brumadinho Fm. tuffaceous materials had
different crystallization ages (ca. 1.4 and ca. 1.2 Ga, respectively). To
distinguish their source, we compared the Lu–Hf data of the volcanic
and detrital zircon grains.

The Lu–Hf TDM for the zircon grains in the crystal-tuff sample
(Tombador Fm.) were between 3.6 and 1.8 Ga, and the ?Hf values were
between ?8.5 and 8. However, the youngest zircon crystals (according

5.3. The Espinhaço Supergroup and regional correlation

The subsidence, uplift, eustasy and sedimentation rates in the Paleo-
to Mesoproterozoic intracratonic basins were likely similar to the uplift,
eustasy and sedimentation rates that have been observed in modern
intracratonic basins. Thus, Precambrian intracratonic basins contain
unconformity-bound sequences that were deposited over several mil-
lion years. Lacunae present in these sequences may be associated with
continental uplift due to major tectonism.

Traditionally, the Paleo- to Mesoproterozoic ES units were treated as
continuous deposits from 1.7 to 0.9 Ga (e.g., Martins-Neto, 2000). Gaps
in the sedimentary record of the long-lived Paleo- to Mesoproterozoic
intracratonic basins have been identified, by using U–Pb geochronology
(Fernandez-Alonso et al., 2012; Ribeiro et al., 2013), especially regarding
Please cite this article as: Guadagnin, F., et al., Age constraints on crystal-tu
to Mesoproterozoic intracratonic..., Gondwana Research (2013), http://dx
the ES (Danderfer et al., 2009; Chemale et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013;
Silveira et al., 2013).

5.3.1. Lower Espinhaço Basin (Statherian IF basin)
The Lower Espinhaço sequence commenced immediately after the

Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle (2.2 to 2.0 Ga) and following intra-
plate rifting of the Congo–São Francisco Craton (e.g., Brito Neves et al.,
1979).

The sedimentary and volcanic rocks from the first basinal cycle were
deposited from 1.80 Ga to 1.68 Ga and are well exposed in Southern
Espinhaço, Northern Espinhaço and Chapada Diamantina as an internal
fracture basin (IF, after Kingston et al., 1983). The Statherian section in-
cludes the basal portion of the Diamantina Group in Southern Espinhaço,
the Oliveira dos Brejinhos Group in Northern Espinhaço and the Rio dos
Remédios Group at Chapada Diamantina (Fig. 9; Martins-Neto, 2000;
Pedreira and De Waele, 2008; Danderfer et al., 2009; Chemale et al.,
2012; Santos et al., 2013).

In Southern Espinhaço, the Statherian rifting event is represented by
typical rift deposits that contain alluvial fan conglomerates, braided flu-
vial and eolian sandstones (from the Bandeirinha and São João da
Chapada Fms.; Santos et al., 2013) and bimodal magmatism from alka-
line to peralkaline acid and SiO2-undersaturated potassic alkaline
compositions (Chemale et al., 2012, and references therein). The acid-
alkaline magmatism in Southern Espinhaço is represented by Conceição
do Mato Dentro rhyolite and Borrachudo-type plutonic bodies that were
crystallized between 1.75 and 1.70 Ga with an Archean crustal residence
time (Nd model ages approximately 3.0 to 2.8 Ga; Brito Neves et al.,

thought to result from the melting of lower anhydrous crustal sources
that have alkaline to peralkaline signatures (Chemale et al., 1998). The
middle portion of the São João da Chapada Fm. is cut by SiO2-
undersaturated and highly K-alkaline magma (hematite–phyllite) with
ages between 1.72 and 1.70 Ga (Dussin, 1994; Chemale et al., 2012).

A similar section can be observed in Northern Espinhaço and at
Chapada Diamantina. The basal section of the Lower Espinhaço Basin
contains eolian and alluvial sediments from the Algodão and Serra da
Gameleira Fms. These sediments are interlayered and are overlain by
the alkaline acid lavas and tuffs of the São Simão and Novo Horizonte
Fms. (Fig. 9; Guimarães et al., 2005; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012).
This acid magmatism was dated between 1.75 and 1.73 Ga by
Schobbenhaus et al. (1994), Babinski et al. (1999) and Danderfer et al.
(2009). The Lagoa Real alkaline-to-peralkaline pluton, which occurs
south and southwest of Chapada Diamantina, is dated at 1724 ± 5 Ma
(Turpin et al., 1988). This pluton is interpreted as cogenetic with the
magmatism of the Oliveira dos Brejinhos and Rio dos Remédios groups
(Fig. 9).

These units are succeeded by continental alluvial, fluvial, eolian and
lacustrine sediments in the Pajeú and Sapiranga Fms. in Northern
Espinhaço, and in the Lagoa de Dentro and Ouricuri do Ouro Fms. at
Chapada Diamantina (Fig. 9; Guimarães et al., 2005; Alkmim and
Martins-Neto, 2012).

Basinal development was associated with a regional extensional event
that occurred after the orogenetic completion of the Transamazonian/
Eburnean cycle collage of the Columbia Supercontinent (Rogers and
Santosh, 2002; Meert, 2012; Ernst et al., 2013b). This widespread acid
alkaline magmatism may be related to plume activity during the late
Paleoproterozoic (Statherian).

5.3.2. Middle Espinhaço Basin (Calymmian rift-sag basin)
The stratigraphic units of the Middle Espinhaço Basin were deposit-

ed between 1.60 and 1.38 Ga. These sequences are exposed only in
Northern Espinhaço and at Chapada Diamantina as a rift-sag basin.
Although it was identified detrital zircon ages between 1.60 and
1.38 Ga in the Upper Espinhaço Basin units in the Southern Espinhaço
range (Chemale et al., 2012), the Calymmian sedimentation is not pre-
served in this region.

In Northern Espinhaço, the rifting episode is represented by the
deposition of alluvial fans, braided fluvial, eolian, deltaic, lacustrine
and volcanic packages of the Bomba Fm. and overlying sediments. The
Bomba Fm. occurs at the top of the Middle Espinhaço section in the
Northern Espinhaço and is composed of intermediate to acid volcanic
lavas that were formed between 1582 ± 8 Ma and 1569 ± 14 Ma
(Fig. 9; Danderfer et al., 2009).

At Chapada Diamantina, the Middle Espinhaço initiated with low-
stand, alluvial-fluvial and eolian sedimentation of the Mangabeira Fm.
and was followed by transgressive shallow-marine to high-stand deltaic
sediments of the Açuruá Fm. (Guimarães et al., 2005). A tholeiitic mafic
dyke swarm, which intruded the basal portion of the Mangabeira Fm.,
was formed at 1514 ± 22 Ma (Babinski et al., 1999) and at 1501 ±
9.1 Ma (Silveira et al., 2013). This intrusion constrains the minimum
depositional age of this unit. These lithological units are interpreted as
typical sag sequences (Fig. 9).

The overlying units that belong to the Tombador Fm. (where our
crystal-rich volcaniclastic rocks were dated at 1436 ± 26 Ma) repre-
sent a new sag phase. The Tombador Fm. was deposited with an angular
unconformable relationship with the underlying Açuruá Fm. and with
a significant change of source area (Pedreira, 1994; Pedreira and De
Waele, 2008). The volcanic activity, angular unconformity and sedimen-
tary source direction change for the fluvial environment suggested that
intraplate tectonic movement occurred before and/or during the depo-
sition of the Tombador Fm. (see discussion Section 5.1).
Please cite this article as: Guadagnin, F., et al., Age constraints on crystal-tu
to Mesoproterozoic intracratonic..., Gondwana Research (2013), http://dx
This new basin cycle (1.60 to 1.38 Ga) in the intraplate setting of the
Congo–São Francisco Craton exhibited a significant increase in sedimen-
tary input and coeval magmatism at 1.4 Ga (the top of Tombador Fm.).
This basinal cycle potentially resulted from extensional tectonics at the
margin of the Congo–São Francisco Craton (De Waele et al., 2008; Tack
et al., 2010; Ernst et al., 2013b).

5.3.3. Upper Espinhaço Basin (Stenian–Tonian rift-sag basin)
The Upper Espinhaço Basin is exposed in Southern and Northern

Espinhaço and at Chapada Diamantina. This sequence was deposited
between 1.19 and 0.9 Ga (Fig. 9).

In Southern Espinhaço, the basal section of the Upper Espinhaço
units consists of diamond-bearing Sopa–Brumadinho Fm. (approxi-
mately 1.19–1.17 Ga) that unconformably overlies the São João da
Chapada Fm. (approximately 1.70 Ga) at the top of the Lower Espinhaço
Basin (Fig. 9; Chemale et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013). Chemale et al.
(2012) observed conglomerate layers with a greenish matrix in the
Sopa–Brumadinho Fm. This matrix possesses an alkali acid chemical sig-
nature. The youngest zircon population of the greenish matrix is dated
at 1192 Ma and is estimated to be the age of the volcanic event. This
youngest zircon population established the maximum depositional
age for the Upper Espinhaço sequence (Chemale et al., 2012). The zircon
grains have Hf model ages of between 2.7 and 1.52 Ga and ?Hf values of
between ?27.2 and 4.7 (see Section 5.2). These values demonstrate
that the zircons have juvenile and recycled signatures (Fig. 8). The
Sopa–Brumadinho Fm. is overlain by the Galho do Miguel Fm. eolian-
marine sediments and the Conselheiro Mata Group shallow marine
platform sediments (Fig. 9; Martins-Neto, 2000). The Upper Espinhaço
Basin accounts for more than 70% of the total stratigraphic thickness
in Southern Espinhaço.

The coeval section of the Conselheiro Mata Group is well exposed at
Chapada Diamantina and is represented by shallow marine sedimenta-
tion (tidal and supratidal sediments) in the Caboclo and Morro do
Chapéu Fms. (Fig. 9; Pedreira, 1994; Pedreira and De Waele, 2008).
The Caboclo carbonates were dated by the Pb–Pb method at 1140 ±
140 Ma (Babinski et al., 1993). We interpreted this marine sequence
as transgressive and paraconformable with underlying units of the
Tombador Fm.

In the Northern Espinhaço, the basal units comprise thick packages of
eolian sediments that belong to the Bom Retiro Fm. (Fig. 9; Loureiro et al.,
2008). The transgressive marine sediments are represented by the dom-
inant pelitic section of the Riacho do Bento (base) and Fazedinha Fms.
(top), which are interlayered with sandstone and pelites of the Mosquito
Fm. (Fig. 9; Loureiro et al., 2008; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). These
units are regionally correlated with the Conselheiro Mata Group and the
Cabloco and Morro do Chapéu Fms. (Southern Espinhaço and Chapada
Diamantina, respectively; Fig. 9).

The rifting of the Congo–São Francisco Craton is directly linked to the
fragmentation of the Rodinia Supercontinent, and started at 0.9 Ga with
the emplacement of mafic tholeiitic dyke swarms and gabbroic bodies
(Silva et al., 1995; Rosset et al., 2007; Evans et al., 2010; Silveira et al.,
2013). These magmatic bodies intruded the entire Espinhaço sequences
and constrain the minimum age for the ES deposition (Fig. 9). In Southern
Espinhaço, this event was dated to 933 ± 20 Ma and 906 ± 2 Ma
(Machado et al., 1989; Abreu, 1991; Dussin and Chemale, 2011; Supple-
mentary Fig. 10), and at Chapada Diamantina the dyke swarms were
dated to 934 ± 14 Ma (Loureiro et al., 2008). The Northern Espinhaço
project (Danderfer et al., 2009) dated the mafic dyke swarms that cut
units of the Lower Espinhaço sequence. These authors used only one
zircon to calculate a magmatic age of 854 ± 23 Ma (MSWD = 6.7;
Danderfer et al., 2009). However, we recalculated the age using all
three Neoproterozoic dated zircon crystals. These crystals were some-
what discordant, which resulted in an age of 890 ± 130 Ma (Fig. 9).

Here, the Upper Espinhaço was hypothesized to result from intra-
plate sedimentation with a strong influence from the late Kibaran or
Grenvilian events and resulting from the compressional tectonism at

the margins of the Congo Craton (as described by Kokonyangi et al.,
2006; De Waele et al., 2008; Fernandez-Alonso et al., 2012). The final
basinal cycle that was observed in the ES likely resulted from events
that were associated with the assembly of Rodinia. This cycle is similar
to the Neopaleozoic sedimentation cycles that were described for the
Central Australian Basins during the Alice Spring Orogeny (Lindsay
and Leven, 1996; Haddad et al., 2001; Lindsay, 2002) and for the Paraná
Basin (South America) during the Gondwanides (Milani and Ramos,
1998), when Pangea assembled.

6. Conclusions

Our U–Pb and Lu–Hf zircon data provided important constraints
regarding the Paleo- and Mesoproterozoic sedimentary evolution of
the Congo–São Francisco Craton as part of the Columbia–Rodinia
supercontinental cycle. The U–Pb zircon age of 1436 ± 26 Ma obtained
from the crystal-tuff in the upper section of the Tombador Fm. confirms
the presence of the Middle Espinhaço Basin in the São Francisco Craton
with underlying units of the Mangabeira and Açuruá Fms. The detrital
zircon grains indicated that a shift occurred in the source area near
the top of the Tombador Fm. The lower Tombador Fm. contains only
inherited zircon grains. However, the upper section contains the base-
ment (older than 1.8 Ga) and Mesoproterozoic grains. The major contri-
butions corresponded to the main cycles of accretion and reworking in
the Congo–São Francisco Craton basement rocks and occurred between
3.4 and 3.2 Ga, 2.8 and 2.5 Ga and 2.1 and 1.9 Ga. In addition, two
important zircon age populations (between 1.8 and 1.7 and 1.6 and
1.5 Ga) were identified in the detrital record and were related to the
reworking of the Lower Espinhaço Basin materials.

The 1.4 Ga Tombador Fm. crystal-tuff zircon Lu–Hf model ages
(TDM) were primarily older than 2.0 Ga. However, the zircon grains
from the 1.19 Ga Sopa–Brumadinho Fm. tuffaceous conglomerate ma-
trix had a TDM of less than 1.9 Ga. This result suggests that different
magmatic sources contributed the volcanic material.

A correlation between the ES units in the São Francisco Craton in the
Southern and Northern Espinhaço ranges and at Chapada Diamantina is
presented here. The Lower Espinhaço Statherian rift basin (1.80 to
1.68 Ga) is well recorded in the three regions and is represented by
bimodal magmatism and by alluvial to fluvial sediments. The Middle
Espinhaço was deposited during the Calymmian period (1.6–1.4 Ga)
as a (rift-)sag basin with eolian, fluvial-deltaic and marine sediments.
These deposits are only exposed at Chapada Diamantina and in Northern
Espinhaço. The last basinal cycle, the Upper Espinhaço Basin, formed
during the Stenian–Tonian (1.19–0.90 Ga) as a rift-sag basin and was
exposed in three regions.

Thus, the time span from 1.80 to 0.90 Ga was recorded in the craton
interior based on three first-order intracratonic basin development cycles
that were limited by major unconformities and related to global tectonics.
The first cycle is related to the intraplate geodynamics that occurred after
the collage of the Columbia Supercontinent in the Transamazonian/
Eburnean orogenies. The second basin cycle, the Middle Espinhaço, was
strongly influenced by the extensional stages of the Karagwe–Ankolian
Belt and the Kunene Complex at the southeastern and western margins
of the Congo Craton, respectively (Tack et al., 2010; Fernandez-Alonso
et al., 2012; Ernst et al., 2013b). The third basin cycle, the Upper
Espinhaço, is directly connected to the Grenvillian/Late Kibaran event
during the formation of the Rodinia Supercontinent (De Waele et al.,
2008).

The aggregation and dispersal of supercontinents have the potential to
create conditions that affect the development and preservation of long-
lived intracratonic basins. This scenario was recognized during the forma-
tion of the Pangea Supercontinent, whose dispersed pieces preserved
several intracratonic basins, such as the Paraná, Central Australian,
Karoo and North American basins. Recognizing chronocorrelate de-
positional cycles in the Precambrian intracratonic basin can be useful
in testing supercontinental reconstructions (i.e., Columbia/Rodinia). The

detailed petrological, sedimentological-stratigraphic and isotopic studies
of the Paleo- to Mesoproterozoic intraplate basins in the Congo–São
Francisco Craton, the Tocantins Province and the Amazonian Craton of
the South American Platform may provide important insights into the
supercontinent theory.

Abstract 23 

A provenance analysis of one of the largest Precambrian intracratonic basins in 24 

the Brazilian Shield, i.e., the Espinhaço basin, provides clues on the source 25 

rocks’ location, composition, and tectonic setting, in addition to providing 26 

information on the tectonic evolution of the Congo–São Francisco paleoplate. 27 

Middle and Upper Espinhaço sequences, deposited from ca. 1.6 to 0.9 Ga, 28 

were investigated by sandstone petrography and geochemistry and detrital 29 

zircon U–Pb and Lu–Hf methods, along with stratigraphic data, to reveal four 30 

distinct provenance patterns. The sandstones preserved in the Mangabeira 31 

Formation were recycled from a sedimentary source; the zircon grains were 32 

Paleoproterozoic, either juvenile or evolved from Mesoarchean or Neoarchean 33 

crustal sources. The Açuruá Formation sandstones were derived from recycling 34 

Manuscript
Click here to view linked References

http://ees.elsevier.com/precam/viewRCResults.aspx?pdf=1&docID=3148&rev=0&fileID=265967&msid={5171EDFB-1EEF-4813-8C17-739F87C72F42}


of sedimentary sources and contain juvenile and remelted zircon grains formed 35 

in the Paleoarchean, Neoarchean, and Paleoproterozoic Eras. The Lower 36 

Tombador Formation presents similar provenance patterns as the Açuruá 37 

Formation, but a significant migration of the depocenter occurred. The overlying 38 

units, the Upper Tombador and Caboclo Formations, include significant inputs 39 

from Statherian and Calymmian zircon grains in addition to the Archean and 40 

Paleoproterozoic grains. The results point to a stratigraphic inversion of the 41 

source area within the Mangabeira to Açuruá Formations, due to the denudation 42 

of the Gavião Block; and a change of provenance from Lower to Upper 43 

Tombador Formations, with the input of Statherian and Calymmian zircons 44 

derived from the lower sequences of the Espinhaço Supergroup and coeval 45 

magmatism. Additionally, the ages and Hf isotopic compositions of zircon grains 46 

older than 1.8 Ga match the evolution of the continental crust within the São 47 

Francisco Craton. Paleogeographic implications of the provenance analysis 48 

were summarized in five time-slices and helped to improve the understanding of 49 

the evolution of the São Francisco Craton. 50 

 51 

Keywords 52 

Intracratonic basins; Provenance analysis; U–Pb detrital zircon geochronology; 53 

Lu–Hf detrital zircon isotope geochemistry; Congo–São Francisco Craton 54 

 55 

1. Introduction 56 

 Cratonic basins are large elliptical continental areas located away from 57 

tectonic plate boundaries and subjected to prolonged subsidence associated 58 

with very low-rates of continental stretching (Armitage and Allen, 2010; Allen 59 

and Allen, 2013). The initial forming mechanism of cratonic basins is commonly 60 

replaced by others during the lifetime of these long-lived basins, which leads to 61 

long periods of subsidence punctuated by episodes of uplift (e.g., DeRito et al., 62 

1983; Leighton, 1990; Allen and Armitage, 2012; Pinet et al., 2013). The 63 

subsidence/uplift pattern of cratonic basins results in the preservation of 64 

continental to shallow-water marine deposits through several sequences 65 

delimited by regional unconformities (Sloss, 1963; Einsele, 2000; Lindsay, 66 

2002; Roberts and Bally, 2012). The stratigraphic record of these basins reveals 67 

the evolution of the sedimentary environments through time, and the 68 



terrigenous grains provide important clues about the composition, age, and 69 

tectonic setting of the source areas, in addition to information about the 70 

paleoclimatic conditions and sedimentary transport processes (e.g., Dickinson 71 

et al., 1983; Ross et al., 1992; McLennan et al., 1993; Cawood et al., 2003; 72 

Najman, 2006; Garzanti et al., 2009; von Eynatten and Dunkl, 2012). Cratonic 73 

basins were often considered to be formed after a supercontinent assembly and 74 

controlled by subsequent tectonic evolution, as in the case of the Paraná, 75 

Karoo, Central European, West Siberian, Central Australian, and Hudson 76 

basins (Lindsay, 2002; Vyssotski et al., 2006; Maystrenko et al., 2008; Milani 77 

and De Wit, 2008; Pinet et al., 2013). Indeed, the study of cratonic basins can 78 

provide unique paleogeographic information on past continents and the 79 

evolution of supercontinents (Leighton, 1996; Lindsay, 2002; Sears et al., 80 

2004). 81 

 During the time period between ca. 2.2 and 1.8 Ga, a series of orogenies 82 

supposedly assembled most of the Archean terrains to form a single continental 83 

mass. These orogenies serve as a geological evidence for the existence of 84 

Columbia supercontinent (e.g., Rogers and Santosh, 2002; Zhao et al., 2002a; 85 

Leite et al., 2009; Meert, 2012; Zhang et al., 2012; Ma et al., 2013; Wu et al., 86 

2014). The Archean terrains that comprise the basement of the present-day 87 

São Francisco and Congo cratons were agglutinated during this time period by 88 

the Transamazonian/Eburnean orogenies (Barbosa and Sabaté, 2002, 2004; 89 

Zhao et al., 2002b). However, the participation of the proto-Congo–São 90 

Francisco Craton in the Columbia supercontinent is not completely understood 91 

primarily because of the lack of reliable age constraints and paleomagnetic 92 

poles (Zhao et al., 2002b; Pisarevsky et al., 2014). Through the identification of 93 

large igneous provinces, mainly occurring as regional-scale radiating dyke 94 

swarms, Ernst et al. (2013) proposed a connection between the Congo–São 95 

Francisco Craton and the Siberia Craton during the Mesoproterozoic Era. 96 

Pisarevsky et al. (2014) tested this hypothesis with reliable paleomagnetic data 97 

and concluded that this connection is possible but not completely provable with 98 

the available data. 99 

  The Congo–São Francisco Craton evolved between 1.8 and 0.9 Ga 100 

through the development of a series of long-lived cratonic basins that recorded 101 

unconformity bounded sequences. The Espinhaço Supergroup (ES) 102 



corresponds to one of these Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic 103 

basins (Pedreira and De Waele, 2008; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; 104 

Chemale et al., 2012; Fernandez-Alonso et al., 2012; Ribeiro et al., 2013; 105 

Santos et al., 2013; Guadagnin et al., in press). These sequences recorded the 106 

landscape evolution in the interior of the Congo–São Francisco Craton from the 107 

craton amalgamation in the Paleoproterozoic Era to its partial break-up in the 108 

early Neoproterozoic Era. The study of the ES sequences can potentially aid 109 

paleogeographic reconstructions of the Columbia supercontinent (Danderfer et 110 

al., in press). 111 

 This paper presents the findings of a provenance analysis conducted on 112 

sandstones from the ES by identifying the location, composition, and tectonic 113 

setting of the source areas, which helps in improving the available 114 

paleogeographic models. The studied interval crops out in the Chapada 115 

Diamantina basin, where it corresponds to the least-deformed and well-exposed 116 

sectors of the ES in the São Francisco craton. Based on a sequence 117 

stratigraphic framework, the sandstone samples were collected in specific 118 

stratigraphic intervals deposited from ca. 1.6 to 0.9 Ga during the 119 

Mesoproterozoic to early Neoproterozoic Eras. Stratigraphic information, 120 

combined with U–Pb geochronology and Lu–Hf isotope geochemistry in detrital 121 

zircon grains, as well as petrography and whole-rock geochemistry, allowed 122 

identifying the main source areas, age, and tectonic setting of the source rocks, 123 

as well as the evolution of the source areas through time. Moreover, the 124 

implications of the provenance analysis for the São Francisco Craton 125 

paleogeographic evolution during the Mesoproterozoic Era are discussed. 126 

 127 

2. Geologic setting 128 

 The São Francisco Craton is formed through accretion of Archean–129 

Paleoproterozoic igneous and metamorphic rocks, comprising the craton 130 

basement and the Paleoproterozoic–Phanerozoic sedimentary cover (e.g., 131 

Almeida, 1977; Barbosa et al., 2004; Cruz and Alkmim, 2006; Alkmim and 132 

Martins-Neto, 2012). The craton regional configuration is marked by a western 133 

and an eastern domain separated by the central Paramirim Aulacogen (Figs. 1a 134 

and 1b; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012 and references therein). Each of these 135 

three features is composed of basement rocks and cover sequences (Fig. 1b). 136 



In the study area, the ES is exposed in the Paramirim Aulacogen, which 137 

corresponds to a NS trending structure developed after 1.75 Ga (Cruz and 138 

Alkmim, 2006; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). 139 

 The basement of the São Francisco Craton in the eastern domain 140 

presents several NS striking shear zones separating the four major geologic 141 

and isotopic distinct terrains: the Gavião, Serrinha, and Jequié blocks, and the 142 

Itabuna–Salvador–Curaçá Belt (Figs. 1c and S1). These blocks generally 143 

include Archean tonalite–trondhjemite–granodiorite suites (TTG) and Archean–144 

Paleoproterozoic greenstone belt terrains that were partially reworked during 145 

the Neoarchean (Jequié Cycle) and Paleoproterozoic Eras 146 

(Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle; Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004; Barbosa et al., 147 

2004; Cruz et al., 2012). 148 

 The Gavião Block is the oldest tectonic unit and occurs in three domains 149 

of the São Francisco Craton. In the Paramirim Aulacogen, the Gavião Block 150 

formed the substratum for the ES deposition (Fig. 1c). The Gavião Block was 151 

formed in the Paleoarchean Era by the emplacement of juvenile TTG gneisses 152 

and the formation of greenstone belt associations (Marinho, 1991; Peucat et al., 153 

2002; Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004; Barbosa et al., 2004). The TTGs yielded 154 

crystallization ages (U–Pb) between 3.38 and 3.2 Ga and Nd model ages 155 

(TDM) between 3.6 and 3.3 Ga (Nutman and Cordani, 1993; Santos-Pinto, 156 

1996; Bastos Leal et al., 1998; Santos-Pinto et al., 2012; Tab. S1). In the 157 

Neoarchean Era, from 2.74 to 2.68 Ga, during the Jequié Cycle, the Gavião 158 

Block was metamorphosed and partially recycled in migmatites and intruded by 159 

alkaline magmas, which were produced from the partial melting of the 160 

Paleoarchean crust (Cruz et al., 2012; Santos-Pinto et al., 2012). In addition, 161 

the formation of the Umburanas greenstone belt occurred during the 162 

Neoarchean Era (ca. 2.74 Ga; Bastos Leal et al., 2003). The final 163 

developmental stages of the Gavião Block were marked by intrusions of pre- 164 

and syntectonic granites, and crustal reworking, during the Paleoproterozoic 165 

Era (Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle; Santos-Pinto, 1996; Peucat et al., 2011; 166 

Santos-Pinto et al., 2012). 167 

 The Jequié Block is separated from the Gavião Block by a narrow fault 168 

zone (Fig. 1c). The Jequié Block corresponds to a granulite terrain composed of 169 

enderbite to charnockite suites, heterogeneous granulites with migmatites, and 170 



inclusions of supracrustal rocks. The granite suites crystallized between 2.8 and 171 

2.45 Ga (U–Pb age) with Nd TDM between 3.1 to 3.0 Ga. The granulite facies 172 

metamorphism in the Jequié Block occurred at ca. 2.0 Ga (Barbosa and 173 

Sabaté, 2004; Barbosa et al., 2004). 174 

 The Serrinha Block occurs at the NE portion of the craton and consists of 175 

basement complexes and supracrustal sequences intruded by Paleoproterozoic 176 

granitoids (Oliveira et al., 2013; Fig. 1c). The basement encompasses 177 

Mesoarchean (3.15–2.9 Ga) and Neoarchean migmatites (2.7–2.6 Ga), banded 178 

gneisses, orthogneisses, mafic dykes, and mafic-ultramafic complexes (Oliveira 179 

et al., 2013). 180 

 The Itabuna–Salvador–Curaçá Belt occurs as a ca. 500 km NS striking 181 

belt separating the Serrinha Block from the Gavião and Jequié blocks. This Belt 182 

is the result of the collision between the three Archean blocks, i.e., Gavião, 183 

Jequié, and Serrinha blocks, during the Paleoproterozoic Era (Barbosa and 184 

Sabaté, 2004; Oliveira et al., 2011). 185 

 The main U–Pb ages and Nd model ages (TDM) for the rocks within the 186 

basement of the São Francisco Craton in the Gavião, Serrinha, and Jequié 187 

blocks, and Itabuna–Salvador–Curaçá Belt is presented in Table S1. These 188 

data plotted in a U–Pb age versus crustal residence time diagram, with distinct 189 

age fields, allowed provenance discrimination (Fig. S1). 190 

 191 

FIGURE 1 192 

 193 

2.1 Sedimentary Cover - ES 194 

 The São Francisco Craton basement is partially covered by 195 

unconformity-bounded Proterozoic- and Phanerozoic-aged sequences (Fig. 1b) 196 

that comprise the Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic Espinhaço, the 197 

Neoproterozoic São Francisco, and the Phanerozoic Sanfranciscana basins 198 

(e.g., Campos and Dardenne, 1997; Martins-Neto, 2000; Alkmim and Martins-199 

Neto, 2012). The sequences register deposition in sedimentary basins probably 200 

due to compressional and/or extensional tectonics at the paleoplate’s interior, in 201 

response to the far-field stresses at the plate margins or due to mantle 202 

dynamics (Chemale et al., 1993; Uhlein et al., 1998). 203 



 The ES was deposited after the Congo–São Francisco Craton 204 

amalgamation at ca. 1.8 Ga and before the craton partial break-up at ca. 0.9 Ga 205 

(Brito Neves et al., 1979; Marshak and Alkmim, 1989; Chemale et al., 1993; 206 

Martins-Neto, 2000; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). The ES sequences were 207 

deformed into large-scale NS striking folds and thrust faults, when the 208 

Gondwana supercontinent assembled in the late Neoproterozoic to early 209 

Paleozoic Eras (Marshak and Alkmim, 1989; Chemale et al., 1993). The 210 

deformation of the ES increases westward (Fig. 2; Chemale et al., 1993; 211 

Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). The ES is exposed in three physiographic 212 

regions, namely the Southern and Northern Espinhaço mountain ranges and 213 

the Chapada Diamantina. These exposures strike roughly in the NS direction, 214 

probably inheriting the pre-existing basement structures (Fig. 1b). 215 

 216 

FIGURE 2 217 

 218 

 The sequence stratigraphic framework of the ES comprises three 219 

megasequences: the Lower, Middle, and Upper Espinhaço sequences 220 

(Chemale et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013; Guadagnin et al., in press). At 221 

Chapada Diamantina, the sequence stratigraphic hierarchy is summarized as 222 

follows: 223 

i) The Lower Espinhaço megasequence consists of the Rio dos 224 

Remédios Group, deposited between ca. 1.8 and 1.68 Ga. This 225 

sequence was not divided into higher-order sequences using sequence 226 

stratigraphic concepts. Based on lithostratigraphic correlations, the Rio 227 

dos Remédios Group encompasses three continental siliciclastic units 228 

separated by a volcanic package. The volcanic rocks include the Novo 229 

Horizonte Formation, aged at ca. 1.75 Ga (Fm.; Schobbenhaus et al., 230 

1994; Babinski et al., 1999), which separates the siliciclastic sequences 231 

of the Serra da Gameleira (below, older than ca. 1.75 Ga) from the 232 

Ouricuri do Ouro and Lagoa de Dentro formations (fms.; above, younger 233 

than ca. 1.75 Ga; Fig. 2). The Serra da Gameleira and Ouricuri do Ouro 234 

fms. comprise continental terrigenous deposits, whereas the Lagoa de 235 

Dentro Fm. contain fluvio-lacustrine intervals (Barbosa and Domingues, 236 



1994; Pedreira, 1994; Andrade et al., 1999; Guimarães et al., 2005; 237 

Loureiro et al., 2008; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). 238 

ii) The Middle Espinhaço megasequence at Chapada Diamantina can be 239 

further subdivided into the lower and upper portions. The lower portion of 240 

the Middle Espinhaço sequence was deposited between ca. 1.6 and 1.5 241 

Ga and is composed of the Mangabeira (older than ca. 1.5 Ga) and 242 

Açuruá fms. (younger than ca. 1.5 Ga), belonging in the Paraguaçú 243 

Group (Fig. 2; Pedreira, 1994; Pedreira and De Waele, 2008; Guimarães 244 

et al., 2005; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; Guadagnin et al., in press). 245 

The Mangabeira Fm. consists of a thick package of eolian deposits that 246 

is overlain by deltaic to shallow-water marine deposits of the Açuruá Fm. 247 

(Pedreira, 1994). Mafic sills and dyke swarms intruded the intermediate 248 

portions of the Mangabeira Fm. at ca. 1.5 Ga (Babinski et al., 1999; 249 

Silveira et al., 2013). The upper section of the Middle Espinhaço 250 

sequence was deposited between ca. 1.45 to 1.38 Ga. At Chapada 251 

Diamantina, this sequence comprises a major part of the Tombador Fm., 252 

which is a lithostratigraphic unit at the base of the Chapada Diamantina 253 

Group (Fig. 2; Pedreira, 1994; Guimarães et al., 2005;). The Tombador 254 

Fm. was subdivided into two units. The Lower Tombador Fm. (older than 255 

ca. 1.4 Ga) is defined by a southeastward retrogradation of fluvio-256 

estuarine systems, whereas the Upper Tombador Fm. (deposited at ca. 257 

1.4 Ga; Guadagnin et al., in press) is characterized by an abrupt change 258 

of the fluvial paleocurrents and by facies related to a regressive alluvial 259 

depositional system (Fig. 2c; Bállico, 2012; Magalhães et al., 2014). 260 

iii) The Upper Espinhaço sequence was identified based on stratigraphic 261 

and geochronological data (Bállico, 2012; Guadagnin et al., in press). At 262 

Chapada Diamantina, this sequence encompasses the Caboclo (younger 263 

than 1.4 Ga, possibly deposited at ca. 1.2 Ga; Babinski et al., 1993) and 264 

Morro do Chapéu fms. (older than 0.9 Ga; Fig. 2c). The base of the 265 

Caboclo Fm. consists of a transgressive fluvio-estuarine to shallow-water 266 

marine interval. The top of the Upper Espinhaço sequence is marked by 267 

the presence of fluvial-estuarine strata belonging to the Morro do Chapéu 268 

Fm. (Dominguez, 1992; Pedreira, 1994). 269 

 270 



 The entire section is intruded by mafic dyke swarms of ca. 0.9 Ga, which 271 

define the minimum age for the ES deposition (e.g., Danderfer et al., 2009; 272 

Chemale et al., 2012; Guadagnin et al., in press). 273 

3. Methods 274 

 Through vertical and lateral mapping of facies and depositional systems, 275 

as well as paleocurrents acquisition and gamma-ray logs, Bállico (2012), Born 276 

(2012), and Magalhães et al. (2014) performed high-resolution sequence 277 

stratigraphic analyses in the well exposed strata of the ES at the Chapada 278 

Diamantina region. These authors worked in the least deformed portion, i.e., the 279 

Chapada Diamantina eastern region, analyzing the Paraguaçú and Chapada 280 

Diamantina groups (Middle and Upper Espinhaço sequences) at the Sincorá 281 

and Tombador mountain ranges (Fig. 2a). 282 

 Samples investigated in the present study were collected within this 283 

sequence stratigraphic framework (Fig. 2). A total of 37 samples were obtained 284 

from 11 stratigraphic sections out of 25 previously studied by Bállico (2012), 285 

Born (2012), and Magalhães et al. (2014), including the Barra da Estiva 286 

(southern), Guiné, Fumaça, Pati–Andaraí, Ribeirão, Serrano, Mucugezinho, 287 

Seabra, Pai Inácio, Gameleira, and Jacobina (northern) vertical logs. In 288 

addition, five samples were collected from an accessible and well-known EW 289 

regional cross-section, across BR-242 national road (Fig. 2b; Pedreira, 1994, 290 

1997; Loureiro et al., 2008). Data from the Tombador Fm. presented by 291 

Guadagnin et al. (in press) are used in the results and discussion sections. The 292 

information on the location (geographic coordinates in WGS-1984 datum), 293 

lithology, depositional environment, litho- and sequence stratigraphic hierarchy, 294 

and the analytical procedures applied on the samples are presented in Table 295 

S2. The geographic distribution of the vertical logs and the samples is shown in 296 

Figure 2. 297 

 Thin sections of 23 sandstone samples were prepared for qualitative and 298 

quantitative petrographic analysis. Samples were cut parallel to the current 299 

direction, whenever possible. Structural, textural, and compositional data were 300 

acquired. The framework composition was determined quantitatively using the 301 

Gazzi–Dickinson point-counting method (Table S3; Dickinson, 1970; Zuffa, 302 

1985). Samples were classified according to the Q-F-L scheme (modified from 303 

Folk et al., 1970), and the source area’s tectonic setting was determined using 304 



the Dickinson et al. (1983) Qm-F-Lt diagram. In addition, the post-depositional 305 

diagenetic processes were evaluated. 306 

 Major and trace elements were analyzed in 45 samples at the Acme 307 

Labs. Major elements were used to discriminate provenance composition and 308 

tectonic setting according to discriminant functions of Roser and Korsch (1988) 309 

and Verma and Armstrong-Altrin (2013). Trace and rare-earth elements (REE) 310 

were used to infer provenance composition, tectonic setting, and processes of 311 

sedimentary recycling, as zircon addition (McLennan et al., 1993). The bulk rock 312 

samples were cleaned from any visible alteration. Samples were dried at 60°C 313 

and pulverized until 85% of a 250 g sample segment passed through 200 mesh 314 

sieves. Major oxides were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic 315 

emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) followed by lithium metaborate/tetraborate 316 

fusion and dilute nitric acid digestion of 0.2 g of the sample. Detection limits for 317 

the major oxides were 0.01% except for Fe2O3, which was analyzed down to the 318 

0.04% detection limit. Loss on ignition was measured by sintering the samples 319 

at 1000°C. Refractory and REE were determined by ICP-MS, followed by 320 

lithium metaborate/tetraborate fusion and dilute nitric acid digestion of 0.5 g of 321 

the sample. Precious and base metals were analyzed by ICP-MS after digestion 322 

of 0.5 g of the sample in hot (95°C) Acqua Regia. Detection limits for the minor, 323 

trace, and REE were mainly between 0.01 and 1 ppm. The exception was for 324 

Vanadium (V), which showed detection limit of 8 ppm. The quality control was 325 

made by the following: analyzing duplicate samples to monitor analytical 326 

precision, a reagent blank to measure background, and an aliquot of certified 327 

reference material or inhouse reference material to monitor accuracy for every 328 

34 natural samples. The analytical data and detection limits are reported in the 329 

Table S4 along with the quality control on duplicates, blanks, and standards’ 330 

measurements. The major oxides are presented in a volatile-free basis in Table 331 

S4. Analyses yielding values below the detection limit were set to the detection 332 

limit value.  333 

 Ten sandstone samples were selected for U–Pb dating of detrital zircon 334 

grains in the present study. In addition to the analyzed samples, five samples 335 

from the Tombador Fm., presented by Guadagnin et al. (in press), were used. 336 

Zircon grains were separated from the whole rock sample using conventional 337 

heavy mineral separation techniques. Each sample was comminuted using a 338 



jaw crusher and mill dishes, until its fragments could pass through an 80 mesh 339 

sieve. Later, the grains were separated by gravity using water-based panning, 340 

and the heavy-minerals were magnetically separated using an isodynamic 341 

magnetic separator. The less magnetic heavy-mineral concentrates were 342 

examined under the stereomicroscope and the zircon grains were handpicked 343 

and mounted in epoxy resin disks. The internal structure and texture of the 344 

zircon grains was observed under transmitted and reflected light optical 345 

microscope and using a scanning electron microscope at the Universidade de 346 

Brasília. The backscattered electron images of the analyzed zircon grains are 347 

presented in Figures S2, S3, S4, and S5. 348 

 In situ U–Pb and Lu–Hf isotopic measurements were subsequently 349 

performed by the laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer 350 

(LA-ICPMS) method using a Thermo Finnigan Neptune multicollector-ICPMS 351 

and a Nd:YAG UP213 New Wave laser ablation system at the Geochronology 352 

Laboratory of Universidade de Brasilia. The zircons were first analyzed for U–353 

Pb and then for Lu–Hf isotopes. The analytical procedures follow the methods 354 

presented by Chemale et al. (2011, 2012). U–Pb isotope data were acquired in 355 

static mode with spot sizes of 30 ?m. The data acquisition occurred in 50 cycles 356 

of 1.048 s integration time, and the masses 202, 204, 206, 207, 208, 232, and 357

measured with multiplier ion counting channels and 206, 208, 232, and 238 with 359 

Faraday cups. Laser-induced elemental fractional and instrumental mass 360 

discrimination were corrected using the reference zircon (GJ-1; Jackson et al., 361 

2004). During the zircons analyses, two GJ-1’s were measured after every eight 362 

to ten sample zircon spots. To evaluate the accuracy and precision of the laser-363 

ablation results, we analyzed an internal standard, the PAD1. The external error 364 

was calculated after the propagation error of the GJ-1 mean and the individual 365 

sample zircon (or spot). The reproducibility obtained from the GJ-1 was 0.6% 366

4. Results 400 

 The results from the geochemical analysis on whole rock samples and 401 

the U–Pb and Lu–Hf analysis on detrital zircon grains obtained in the present 402 

work, along with the data published by Guadagnin et al. (in press), are 403 

described below. The results obtained through the petrographic analysis are 404 



also summarized, and the complete description is provided in the 405 

Supplementary Material S1. 406 

 407 

4.1 Sandstone petrography 408 

 The sandstones analyzed by optical microscopy were collected from 409 

alluvial-fluvial, eolian, coastal, and shallow-water marine deposits (Tab. S2). 410 

The textures of the samples varied, considering the wide range of depositional 411 

systems sampled. The framework grains were the dominating fraction of the 412 

components and accounted for 53% to 97% of the total rocks, with a mean 413 

value of 81 ± 12%. Some sandstones were strongly cemented, where the 414 

authigenic fraction amounted to between 20%–47% of the rock. Most samples 415 

did not present any depositional matrix, whereas some samples exhibited a low 416 

matrix content not exceeding 14% (Tab. S3). 417 

 The sandstones’ framework grains contained abundant monocrystalline 418 

(40% <Qm <87%) and relatively less frequent polycrystalline quartz grains (Qp 419 

<15%). The total quartz content (Qt) varied from 45% to 93%, with a mean 420 

quartz content of 75 ± 14%. The rock fragments (Lt) rarely reached 30%, being 421 

absent in half of the samples. When present, the rock fragments were mainly of 422 

sedimentary (sandstones-mudstones and chert) or metamorphic origin with 423 

minor occurrence of plutonic rock fragments. Feldspars (F) were few, varying 424 

from traces up to 8%, and rarely reaching 13%; these are both alkaline and 425 

plagioclase, but they were mostly replaced by diagenetic sericite and illite (Fig. 426 

3). Accessory phases were composed of variable amounts of detrital mica and 427 

heavy minerals such as zircon, tourmaline, and opaque minerals. The 428 

sandstones’ composition was highly mature; quartzarenites predominate, with 429 

minor subarkoses and sublitharenites, and even less frequent litharenites (Fig. 430 

3). 431 

 Mechanical compaction and cementation are responsible for reducing 432 

intergranular porosity. The grain contacts evolved from point-contacts to 433 

concave–convex, and rarely sutured contacts. Labile grains, pelitic rock 434 

fragments, micas, and altered feldspars were deformed by the compaction 435 

processes, eventually generating pseudo-matrix (Fig. 3). Cements mainly 436 

consisted of iron oxide coatings; variable amounts of sintaxial quartz 437 

overgrowths; clay minerals such as kaolinite, pyrophyllite, but mostly illite 438 



occurring as coatings and/or filling the pore spaces and euhedral tourmaline 439 

crystals in some samples. 440 

 441 

FIGURE 3 442 

 443 

4.2 Sandstone geochemistry 444 

 The SiO2 content of the analyzed sandstones ranged from 74.4 to 97.8 445 

wt.% and was inversely related to Al2O3, total mafic components (Fe2O3t + MgO 446 

+ MnO + TiO2), and the total alkali (Na2O + K2O) content (Fig. 4a). The Al2O3 447 

content ranged from 0.9 to 16.6 wt.%, the total mafic components content from 448 

0.5 to 7.6 wt.%, and the total alkali content from 0.05 to 6.4 wt.% (Fig. 4a; Tab. 449 

S4). To test the elemental mobility during weathering and diagenesis, we 450 

applied the approach described by Fralick and Kronberg (1997), which consists 451 

of plotting the SiO2 versus other major oxides. The immobile elements aligned 452 

as a function of rock texture and composition. This approach shows that Al2O3, 453 

Fe2O3t, MgO, K2O, and TiO2 are immobile, whereas Na2O, CaO, and P2O5 are 454 

mobile in the analyzed samples (Fig. S6). The immobile elements may be used 455 

to determine provenance, whereas the mobile elements only provide 456 

information about the weathering and diagenetic processes. When compared to 457 

the composition of the Upper Continental Crust (UCC; Taylor and McLennan, 458 

1985), the analyzed sandstones are slightly enriched in SiO2, apart from a 459 

single sample in the Açuruá Fm. (sample F2), whereas most samples are 460 

depleted in Al2O3, Fe2O3t, MgO, K2O, and TiO2 (Fig. S7). The CaO and Na2O 461 

content of the analyzed sandstones is highly depleted in relation to the UCC 462 

composition, and some samples in the Açuruá and Lower Tombador fms. are 463 

also highly depleted in MgO (Fig. S7). Based on the major elements 464 

composition, samples can be classified from wackes to quartzarenites following 465 

the geochemical classification scheme of Herron (1988; Fig. 4b; Tab. S2). 466 

 467 

FIGURE 4 468 

 469 

 The large ion lithophile element (LILE) content varied from 1112 ppm to 470 

32 ppm with a mean value of 329 ppm in the analyzed sandstones. The LILE 471 

profiles were variable when normalized to the UCC. The Ba and Rb 472 



concentrations are similar to depleted, whereas Sr presents a highly depleted 473 

pattern in relation to the UCC in most samples (Fig. S7). The high field strength 474 

element (HFSE) composition was variable and appears influenced by the Zr 475 

content. The HFSE content varied from 659 to 43 ppm, and the Zr content 476 

varied from 606 to 34 ppm (Tab. S4). The concentrations of Hf, Nb, Ta, Th, and 477 

U ranged from ca. 20 ppm to as low as 0.1 ppm. The Nb and Ta concentrations 478 

were lower than those of the UCC, while the U concentration was similar to 479 

slightly depleted (Fig. S7). Zr and Hf concentrations of the Mangabeira Fm. 480 

sandstones are comparable to those of the UCC, and the Th content was 481 

similar to slightly enriched. However, in the Açuruá and Caboclo fms., the Zr 482 

and Hf profiles exhibit a great range of values, from depleted to enriched 483 

patterns. The Lower Tombador Fm. is slightly depleted in Zr and Hf compared 484 

to the UCC, while the Upper Tombador Fm. is similar to slightly enriched in Zr 485 

and Hf compared to the UCC (Fig. S7). The content of mafic trace elements 486 

was low in the analyzed sandstones. The Sc content varied between 11 ppm 487 

and 1 ppm; the V content between 77 ppm and 4 ppm; the Y content between 488 

37 ppm and 2.5 ppm; the Ni content between 35 ppm and 10 ppm; and the Co 489 

content between 6 ppm to 0.4 ppm (Tab. S4). 490 

 The REE content in the studied samples varied between 272 ppm and 12 491 

ppm; light rare-earth elements (LREE) were enriched compared to heavy rare-492 

earth elements (HREE; Tab. S4). The LREE/HREE ratio ranged between 15.8 493 

and 4.7, while the La/Yb ratio is calculated between 36.6 and 7.3. Teh 494 

sandstones presented negative Eu anomalies (normalized to chondrite values, 495 

Eu/Eu*) ranging from 0.86 to 0.45. The chondrite normalized REE elements 496 

exhibited a variable profile despite enrichment from the chondrite values 497 

(Boynton, 1984; Fig. 4c). In the chondrite normalized plot, the samples exhibited 498 

a pattern of enrichment in LREE relative to the HREE, and a flat HREE pattern 499 

(Fig. 4c). The analyzed sandstones are mainly depleted in REE when compared 500 

to the UCC composition, whereas Mangabeira Fm. samples present a similar 501 

pattern. Açuruá Fm. provided a significant number of samples with similar to 502 

enriched REE as compared to the UCC (Fig. S7). The Eu/Eu* anomalies of the 503 

analyzed samples are similar to the UCC Eu/Eu* anomalies (Fig. S7). Additional 504 

REE geochemical parameters in the analyzed sandstones relative to the UCC 505 

are shown in Figure S7, including La/Yb, La/Ybn, LREE/HREE, (La/Sm)n, and 506 



(Gd/Yb)n ratios, as well as the total REE (?REE) for comparison. The chondrite 507 

normalized ratios are presented in Table S4. 508

4.3 U–Pb detrital zircon ages 510 

 A total of 872 U–Pb zircon age determinations were obtained for this 511 

study, based on ten samples from the ES in the Paraguaçú and Chapada 512 

Diamantina groups. From these, 621 analyses were concordant (71%). The 513 

zircon ages were obtained from the Mangabeira (211) and Açuruá (219) fms. in 514 

the Paraguaçú Group, and from the Tombador (245) and Caboclo (197) fms. in 515 

the Chapada Diamantina Group (Tab. S5). Additionally, 339 concordant U–Pb 516 

ages from the Tombador Fm. (Guadagnin et al., in press) were used, adding up 517 

to a total of 961 detrital zircon ages. 518 

 519 

Mangabeira Fm. 520 

 Two sandstone samples from the Mangabeira Fm. were selected for U–521 

Pb zircon dating, both collected at the Seabra vertical log (samples F5 and F27; 522 

Fig. 2). Sample F27 was collected from eolian and Sample F5 from ephemeral 523 

fluvial deposits. The most frequent concordant U–Pb zircon age population in 524 

the Mangabeira Fm., defined by 118 of 171 analyzes (69%), occurred between 525

5. Discussion 636 

 A synthesis of the analytical data obtained in the present study with 637 

stratigraphic data allows the identification of the source areas location, 638 

composition, and tectonic setting for each individual stratigraphic unit studied. 639 

Furthermore,  integrating the provenance information for the entire section 640 

unravels the evolution of the source areas through time. The petrogenetic 641 

characteristics of detrital zircons stored in the ES at the Chapada Diamantina 642 



basin resemble those at the São Francisco Craton basement. Here, we discuss 643 

the implications of the ES provenance for the tectonic evolution of the São 644 

Francisco Craton. 645 

 646 

5.1 Provenance 647 

 The analysis of the detrital zircon pattern in the studied section suggests 648 

two different types of sediment infilling. The first case requires the stratigraphic 649 

inversion of the source area from the Mangabeira Fm. to the Açuruá Fm.; and 650 

for the second case, the change of detrital zircon age distribution between the 651 

Lower and Upper Tombador Fm. is marked by a change in the source area due 652 

to an uplift of the source region and addition of synsedimentary volcanic 653 

material dated at ca. 1.4 Ga. 654 

 655 

Mangabeira Fm. 656 

 Mangabeira Fm. corresponds to the lower interval of Middle Espinhaço 657 

sequence and records eolian deposits with northeastward directed 658 

paleocurrents (Fig. 2b). The sandstones from the Mangabeira Fm. are 659 

quartzose, but less compositionally mature than those from the other 660 

formations, due to the highest amount of rock fragments. The rock fragments 661 

were mostly sedimentary, but low-grade metamorphic and rare plutonic grains 662 

occurred as well. The samples from the Mangabeira Fm., when plotted on the 663 

Gazzi–Dickinson source area tectonic discrimination diagram, fall in the 664 

recycled orogen field, from transitional to quartzose-recycled (Fig. 3). This 665 

specific composition is related to the uplift of fold and thrust belts on the source 666 

area, providing sands from mainly sedimentary origin and minor proportions 667 

from volcanic sources, partly metamorphosed (Dickinson et al., 1983). The 668 

quartzose characteristic is related to recycling of cratonic sources. The major 669 

and trace elements composition of the Mangabeira Fm. also indicates that the 670 

sands were recycled from a sedimentary source formed in a collisional tectonic 671 

setting (Fig. 7). 672 

 The zircon grains from the Mangabeira Fm. are mostly rounded with 673 

short prisms. Most grains exhibit magmatic zoning in the CL images, some 674 

grains are homogeneous, and few grains present core and rim structure (Figure 675 

S2). The U–Pb ages are mainly clustered between 2.21 and 1.98 Ga 676 



(Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle; Fig. 8). This group of grains has three Lu–Hf 677 

patterns. The first sub-group comprises zircon grains with very negative ?Hf 678 

values (from –20 to –10) and long crustal residence times (from 1108 to 702 679 

Ma), derived from the reworking of Mesoarchean crust within the Gavião Block. 680 

The second sub-group presents ?Hf values from –7 to 0 and crustal residence 681 

times from 610 to 351 Ma, derived from the reworking of Neoarchean crust 682 

formed in the Jequié Cycle. The third sub-group is characterized by juvenile 683 

zircons with ?Hf values from 1 to 6 and short crustal residence times (from 291 684 

to 86 Ma), derived from Paleoproterozoic arc-related units within the Gavião 685 

Block (Figs. 6 and 9). This evidence points to a provenance predominantly from 686 

rocks crystallized in the Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle (2.2 to 2.0 Ga), from 687 

either mantle or crustal sources. Zircon grains with crustal signature are related 688 

to an Archean crust similar to that in the Gavião Block. 689 

 The preservation of eolian sequences implies the availability of sand to 690 

be transported to basins, where the deposition and preservation is controlled by 691 

the balance between the sand supply and the variations in groundwater level 692 

(Rodríguez-Lopes et al., 2014 and references therein). The sandstones 693 

preserved in the Mangabeira Fm. were recycled from a prior sedimentary 694 

source whose first-order source was either juvenile or reworked terrains formed 695 

in a collisional setting between 2.2 and 2.0 Ga (Transamazonian/Eburnean 696 

Cycle). The Paleoproterozoic units within the Gavião Block, located at the S-SW 697 

of the present-day Mangabeira Fm. outcrops, such as Guanambi Batholith 698 

(Rosa et al., 2000; Barbosa et al., 2013), are the most probable primary 699 

sources. These sediments have been reworked by eolian processes and 700 

recycled into the Mangabeira eolian system. We suggest that the sedimentary 701 

source was the deposits within the Lower Espinhaço sequence, such as the 702 

Ouricuri do Ouro and Serra da Gameleira fms. (Fig. 10). 703 

 704

 706

 710 



FIGURE 10 711 

 712 

Açuruá Fm. 713 

 The overlying stratigraphic unit, Açuruá Fm., is the intermediate 714 

formation of the Middle Espinhaço sequence (Guadagnin et al., in press). The 715 

Açuruá Fm. records coastal to shallow-water marine deposits with its main 716 

paleocurrent vectors pointing to the E and NE direction. The Açuruá Fm. 717 

sandstones are more compositionally mature than those from the Mangabeira 718 

Fm. and plot in the craton field of the continental block tectonic provenance 719 

(Fig. 3). The geochemical composition of major and trace elements suggests 720 

that the sandstones from the Açuruá Fm. are derived from recycled sources 721 

associated with collisional setting (Fig. 7). 722 

 The U–Pb ages for the Açuruá Fm. detrital zircons defined three 723 

populations, which corresponded to the three main ages present in the 724 

basement blocks of the São Francisco Craton (Paleoarchean, Neoarchean, and 725 

Paleoproterozoic ages; Figs. 8 and S1). The Paleoarchean zircon grains are 726 

juvenile and derived from Paleoarchean mantle-derived units within the Gavião 727 

Block, probably the oldest TTG suites such as the Boa Vista, Mata Verde, and 728 

Sete Voltas (Tab. S1). The Paleoarchean juvenile zircon grains have ?Hf values 729 

from –5 to 1 and crustal residence time from 380 to 29 Ma. The Neoarchean 730 

zircon grains are either juvenile (?Hf from 0 to 5) or remelted from Eoarchean (?Hf 731 

from –19 to –17) and Mesoarchen (?Hf from –6 to –1) crustal sources (Fig. 9). 732 

The Neoarchean zircons were formed during the Jequié Cycle, from the 733 

reworking of the Eoarchean and Mesoarchean units within Gavião Block or 734 

directly from mantle sources. The Paleoproterozoic grains were remelted from a 735 

Neoarchean source in the Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle. Those zircons 736 

present ?Hf values from –9 to –5 and crustal residence time from 693 to 521 Ma 737 

(Fig. 9). This evidence suggests that the source areas for this stratigraphic unit 738 

was primarily formed during the Eoarchean and Paleoarchean, and they were 739 

either juvenile or subjected to successive cycles of crustal reworking in the 740 

Neoarchean (Jequié Cycle) and Paleoproterozoic eras 741 

(Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle; Fig. 6). The Archean/Paleoproterozoic units 742 

within the Gavião Block indeed meet these premises (Tab. S1). 743 



 The source region for the Açuruá Fm. is located south and west of the 744 

present-day outcrops of this unit. The coastal to shallow-water marine deposits 745 

of the Açuruá Fm. records sandstones with high compositional maturity, 746 

reflecting successive cycles of recycling and/or long distances of transport and 747 

intense weathering conditions (Dickinson et al., 1983). Unlike Mangabeira Fm. 748 

sandstones, the Açuruá Fm. sandstones present significant amounts of 749 

Paleoarchean and Neoarchean zircons in addition to the Paleoproterozoic 750 

grains. This change of detrital zircon pattern reflects a change in source area 751 

due to the stratigraphic inversion of the source region associated with the 752 

progressive denudation of basement sources exposing older units of the Gavião 753 

Block (Fig. 10). 754 

 755 

Tombador Fm. 756 

 The Tombador Fm. corresponds to the upper interval of the Middle 757 

Espinhaço sequence. It is subdivided into the Lower and Upper Tombador Fm. 758 

based on an abrupt change of facies from fluvio-estuarine to alluvial systems, 759 

significant change of paleocurrents from NW to SW (Fig. 2c; Bállico, 2012; 760 

Magalhães et al., 2014), and change in the detrital zircon pattern, as already 761 

discussed by Guadagnin et al. (in press) and is further discussed below. 762 

 Petrographic analyses show that the Tombador Fm. sandstones have 763 

craton interior of quartzose-recycled tectonic provenance (Fig. 3), which is 764 

reinforced by the geochemical data that points out to a recycled provenance 765 

either related to collisional or rift tectonic setting (Fig. 7). The detrital zircon age 766 

pattern of the Tombador Fm. shows a clear change in source area from Lower 767 

to Upper Tombador fms. (Fig. 8). The Lower Tombador Fm. shows similar 768 

zircon age pattern as the Açuruá Fm., with three well-defined age clusters (Figs. 769 

5 and 8). The Paleoarchean grains are juvenile and present ?Hf values from –6 770 

to 2 and crustal residence time from 388 to 110 Ma; the Neoarchean grains are 771 

juvenile and remelted from Paleoarchean to Mesoarchean crust with ?Hf values 772 

from –11 to –5 and crustal residence time from 650 to 448 Ma. The juvenile 773 

Neoarchean grains have ?Hf values from –3 to 1 and crustal residence time from 774 

409 to 220 Ma. The main Paleoproterozoic zircon grains are remelted from a 775 

Neoarchean crust, with ?Hf values from –13 to –2 and crustal residence time 776 

from 824 to 394 Ma (Fig. 9; Tabs. 1 and S6). The Upper Tombador Fm. shows 777 



an additional population of zircon grains younger than 1.8 Ga and a decrease of 778 

the Paleoarchean and Neoarchean grains (Fig. 8). The zircon grains younger 779 

than 1.8 Ga occur in three groups: i) the Statherian zircon grains (U–Pb ages 780 

between 1.81 and 1.75 Ga) were derived from the remelting of a Rhyacian crust 781 

(Transamazonian/Eburnean Cycle) with ?Hf values from –7 to 3 and crustal 782 

residence time from 605 to 280 Ma; ii) the Calymmian zircons (U–Pb ages 783 

between 1.58 and 1.55 Ga) were derived from the remelting of a Statherian 784 

crust, have ?Hf values from 0 to 4 and crustal residence time from 420 to 286 785 

Ma; and iii) the Eocalymmian zircon grains (U–Pb ages between 1.47 and 1.39 786 

Ga) were derived from the remelting of a Paleoproterozoic crust with ?Hf values 787 

from –8 to –2 and crustal residence time from 762 to 497 Ma (Fig. 9). 788 

 The Lower Tombador Fm. records unincised fluvial and tide-dominated 789 

estuarine systems supplied from the E-SE (Magalhães et al., 2014). Similar to 790 

the sandstones from the Mangabeira and Açuruá fms., the sandstones from the 791 

Lower Tombador Fm. are typical cratonic quartzarenites derived from recycled 792 

sources (Fig. 3). Based on their geochemical composition, the Lower Tombador 793 

Fm. sandstones originate from collisional terrains or rift settings (Fig. 7). The 794 

detrital zircon pattern of the sandstones from the Lower Tombador Fm. is 795 

similar to the Açuruá Fm. detrital zircon pattern, and is a record of the 796 

denudation of basement terrains (Figs. 5, 6, 8, and 9). The Upper Tombador 797 

Fm. exposes braided fluvial, eolian, and alluvial systems supplied from the E-798 

NE (Bállico, 2012). Petrographically, there is no clear difference between the 799 

Lower and Upper Tombador Fm. sandstones, despite the addition of juvenile 800 

volcanic fragments in volcaniclastic beds within Upper Tombador Fm. 801 

(Guadagnin et al., in press). Geochemically, the Lower and Upper Tombador 802 

Fm. present a small difference in the UCC normalized Zr and Hf and in the 803 

HREE pattern. Lower Tombador Fm. sandstones have a slightly depleted 804 

pattern in Zr and Hf, as compared to the UCC, and slightly enriched HREE 805 

relative to chondrite; however, sandstones from the Upper Tombador Fm. are 806 

considerably more enriched in HREE pattern relative to the chondrite and are 807 

slightly enriched in Zr and Hf as compared to the UCC (Figs. 4c and S7). 808 

 Despite the whole-rock data that shows small differences between both 809 

successions, the addition of Statherian and Calymmian zircon grains in the 810 

Upper Tombador Fm. marks a clear change in the source area. This change of 811 



source area marks the major subdivision of the Tombador Fm. in two second-812 

order sequences, the Lower and Upper Tombador fms.; this change was 813 

attributable to the deposition of the coarse alluvial strata, the change in the 814 

paleocurrents pattern, and the addition of 1.43 to 1.38 Ga synsedimentary 815 

volcaniclastic material (Figs. 2c, 5, 6, 8, 9, and 10). This volcaniclastic material 816 

recorded in the Upper Tombador Fm. was deposited at ca. 1.43 Ga (Guadagnin 817 

et al., in press) and relates to an important extensional event within the paleo-818 

Congo–São Francisco Craton (Fernandez-Alonso et al., 2012; Ernst et al., 819 

2013; Guadagnin et al., in press; Wu et al., 2014). This extensional event may 820 

have triggered basin reorganization and the development of the alluvial systems 821 

preserved in the Upper Tombador Fm. (Bállico, 2012). The Statherian sources 822 

(ca. 1.75 Ga) are related to the reworking of the Lower Espinhaço sequence, 823 

and the Calymmian sources (ca. 1.58 to 1.5 Ga) are derived from the erosion of 824 

the magmatic rocks recorded in the Northern Espinhaço range, such as the 825 

volcanic units within Pajeú Group (Danderfer et al., 2009) and the erosion of 826 

dykes and sills that intrude the Congo–São Francisco Craton (e.g., Ernst et al., 827 

2013; Silveira et al., 2013). 828 

 Moreover, the lateral variation in the detrital zircon pattern from southern 829 

(Ribeirão vertical log; Fig. 2) to northern sectors (Jacobina and Gameleira 830 

vertical logs; Fig. 2), as observed in Figure 5 (Samples P1, P2, and G21), is 831 

related to different source areas. The erosion of sedimentary sources of the 832 

Lower Espinhaço sequence in southern sectors and basement sources in the 833 

northern sectors (Fig. 10) resulted in a natural bias in the detrital zircon age 834 

spectra (Figs. 2 and 5). 835 

 836 

Caboclo Fm. 837 

 The Caboclo Fm. corresponds to the lower interval of the Upper 838 

Espinhaço sequence (Bállico, 2012; Guadagnin et al., in press) and was 839 

deposited in coastal to shallow marine environments. The paleocurrent vectors 840 

point to the SW direction. The sandstones from the Caboclo Fm. are dominated 841 

by quartz with very low lithic and feldspar grains (Fig. 3). In the Gazzi–Dickinson 842 

diagram, the samples from the Caboclo Fm. are plotted between quartzose-843 

recycled and craton fields of the recycled orogen and continental block tectonic 844 

provenances (Fig. 3). According to the geochemical composition of major and 845 



trace elements, the sandstones from the Caboclo Fm. derive from recycled 846 

sources from collisional to rift settings (Fig. 7). 847 

 The U–Pb age spectra of the detrital zircons from the Caboclo Fm. is 848 

similar to those of the Upper Tombador Fm., with a major contribution from 849 

Statherian zircons (ca. 46.4% of analyzed grains) along with a similar proportion 850 

of Neoarchean, Rhyacian, and Calymmian zircon grains and minor 851 

Paleoarchean and Mesoarchean grains (Fig. 5). The Paleoarchean and 852 

Mesoarchean grains are either juvenile or recycled from Paleoarchean crustal 853 

sources. The Neoarchean zircon grains are also either juvenile or recycled, 854 

whereas the recycled grains result from the reworking of Paleoarchean to 855 

Meosarchean sources (Fig. 9). The Rhyacian grains are remelted and derive 856 

from the reworking of Mesoarchean to Neoarchean sources, whereas the 857 

Orosirian to Statherian grains derive from the reworking of Rhyacian crustal 858 

sources. The Mesoproterozoic grains (Calymmian) originate from the reworking 859 

of Statherian sources (Fig. 9). 860 

 The sandstones preserved in the coastal to shallow-water marine 861 

deposits of the Caboclo Fm. are supplied from the E-NE, from recycled cratonic 862 

sources (Fig. 10). The detrital zircon pattern is rather similar to that of the Upper 863 

Tombador Fm. These results allow for two hypotheses: i) the Caboclo Fm. 864 

deposits were supplied from similar sources as the Upper Tombador Fm. 865 

deposits, or ii) the Caboclo Fm. sandstones were recycled from the deposits of 866 

the Upper Tombador Fm. The similarity of the zircon grains’ Lu–Hf pattern for 867 

both formations supports both these hypotheses. The youngest zircon grains 868 

(U–Pb age of ca. 1.4 Ga) are more representative in the Upper Tombador Fm. 869 

mainly due to the 1.4 Ga synsedimentary magmatism (Guadagnin et al., in 870 

press). 871 

 Figure 10 illustrates the paleogeographic implications of the provenance 872 

analysis in five time-slices, showing (1) Mangabeira Fm. (older than 1.5 Ga), (2) 873 

Açuruá Fm. (younger than 1.5 Ga), (3) Lower Tombador Fm. (older than 1.4 874 

Ga), (4) Upper Tombador Fm. (deposited at ca. 1.4 Ga), and (5) Caboclo Fm. 875 

(younger than ca. 1.4 Ga, possibly deposited at ca. 1.2 Ga; see section 2). 876 

 877 

5.2 Tectonic evolution of the São Francisco Craton recorded in the ES 878 



 Cratonic basins are the depository of detrital material, either derived from 879 

successive cycles of sedimentary recycling or originating from the denudation of 880 

the continental crust where those basins were formed. The detrital grains 881 

deposited and preserved in the Middle and Upper Espinhaço sequences record 882 

the provenance evolution, as well as the evolution of the continental crust within 883 

the São Francisco Craton. The ages and Hf isotopic composition of detrital 884 

zircons from these sequences provide sufficient information to discuss the 885 

basement tectonic evolution and the evolution of the Mesoproterozoic cover of 886 

the São Francisco Craton. 887 

 The first crustal fragments forming the basement of the São Francisco 888 

Craton evolved from juvenile TTG magmas in the Eoarchean to Paleoarchean 889 

Eras (Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). These units represent the first continental 890 

crusts that hosted the deposition of the Archean Greenstone Belts. During the 891 

Mesoarchean to Neoarchean Eras, a cycle of juvenile magmas intrusion and 892 

crustal reworking occurred (Jequié Cycle, from ca. 2.8 to 2.5 Ga). The Archean 893 

units (juvenile Paleoarchean and juvenile/reworked Neoarchean terrains) were 894 

accreted in the Paleoproterozoic Era during the Transamazonian/Eburnean 895 

orogenic cycle, from ca. 2.2 to 2.0 Ga (Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). This 896 

oversimplified sequence of events resulted in the consolidation of the cratonic 897 

domains of the proto-Congo–São Francisco Craton, whose detrital materials are 898 

stored in the ES (Figs. 5, 6, 8, and 9). The Columbia supercontinent accretion 899 

occurred at the same time period as the amalgamation of the proto-Congo–São 900 

Francisco Craton (Zhao et al., 2002a, 2002b; Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). 901 

 902 

6. Conclusions 903 

 The provenance analysis, using traditional paleocurrent and sandstone 904 

petrographic information, integrated with sandstone geochemistry, and detrital 905 

zircon ages and isotope compositions presented here support the following 906 

conclusions: 907 

 908 

1. The Mangabeira Fm., basal portion of the Middle Espinhaço megasequence, 909 

preserved eolian deposits; these sands were supplied from the S-SW, from a 910 

recycled sedimentary source originally derived from a region of collisional 911 

tectonic setting. The zircon grains formed in the Paleoproterozoic Era during the 912 



Transamazonian/Eburnean orogenetic cycle, when the proto-Congo–São 913 

Francisco Craton agglutinated. The Paleoproterozoic zircons were either 914 

remelted from Mesoarchean, Neoarchean, and Siderian crust or mantle-derived 915 

(juvenile). The most probable source of the Mangabeira eolian sands is the 916 

Lower Espinhaço megasequence such as the Ouricuri do Ouro Fm. (Rio dos 917 

Remédios Group) and/or Serra da Gameleira Fm.) that primarily received sands 918 

from the denudation of a terrain similar to the Guanambi Batholith. 919 

 920 

2. The Açuruá Fm. (intermediate portion of the Middle Espinhaço 921 

megasequence), overlies the Mangabeira Fm. and preserved coastal to 922 

shallow-water marine deposits (marking a transgression of a shallow-sea over 923 

the São Francisco Craton), whose sands were derived from the S-W from a 924 

recycled source. The denudation of the Gavião Block exposed older rocks, 925 

either juvenile Paleoarchean or juvenile and reworked Neoarchean rocks, in 926 

addition to the Paleoproterozoic units. The sediments of the Açuruá Fm. are 927 

typically cratonic, whose sources have been sedimentary recycled or subjected 928 

to long-distances of transport and/or intense weathering. The source area 929 

shifting between the Mangabeira and Açuruá fms. is related to the stratigraphic 930 

inversion of basement sources. The primarily source was the Gavião Block. 931 

 932 

3. The Lower Tombador Fm. overlies the Açuruá Fm. with a well-documented 933 

unconformity and preserves unincised fluvial and tide-dominated estuarine 934 

systems supplied from the E-SE. The source rocks are sedimentary recycled 935 

and related either with collisional or rift settings. The detrital materials primarily 936 

originated from a Paleoarchean crust, either juvenile or reworked, during the 937 

Neoarchean and Paleoproterozoic Eras, such as the Gavião Block. 938 

 939 

4. The Upper Tombador Fm., which is the upper portion of the Middle 940 

Espinhaço megasequence, was defined by an abrupt change of sedimentary 941 

facies and paleocurrent vectors in addition to a shift in the detrital zircon pattern. 942 

The source area migration is related to the addition of Statherian and 943 

Calymmian grains, and it is probably associated with the uplift of the Lower and 944 

Middle Espinhaço sequences and Eocalymmian magmatic manifestation in the 945 



proto-Congo–São Francisco Craton. The possible sources were either recycled 946 

sedimentary or basement, and were related to collisional or rift settings. 947 

 948 

5. The Caboclo Fm. corresponds to the lower interval of the Upper Espinhaço 949 

megasequence and overlies the Upper Tombador Fm. The coastal to shallow-950 

water marine deposits of Caboclo Fm. were supplied from the east. Caboclo 951 

Fm. presents the same provenance pattern as its underlying unit. The similar 952 

U–Pb ages and Hf isotopic compositions of the detrital zircons from the Caboclo 953 

and Upper Tombador fms. suggest reworking of the latter through recycling 954 

processes or an equivalent source area. 955 

 956 

6. The main sedimentary processes in the Espinhaço cratonic basin are related 957 

to the denudation of basement terrains and recycling of Lower and Middle 958 

Espinhaço sequences. The basement provided detrital material, which is 959 

preserved in the studied sections, and reflects the ages and petrogenetic 960 

constraints of the rocks within the São Francisco Craton basement, implying 961 

local sources rather than distant derived material. The addition of Paleoachean 962 

and Neoarchean grains in the Açuruá and Lower Tombador fms. signifies a 963 

case of stratigraphic inversion. The addition of detrital material derived from the 964 

Lower Espinhaço sequence and juvenile volcanic material to the Upper 965 

Tombador Fm. suggests an uplift of the Lower Espinhaço sequences and the 966 

addition of synsedimentary volcanic material. This event may be connected to 967 

the large scale extensional processes at the Congo Craton (Fernandez-Alonso 968 

et al., 2012; Ernst et al., 2013, Wu et al., 2014). 969 

 970 

7. The paleogeographic reconstructions of the Paleoproterozoic and 971 

Mesoproterozoic cratonic sequences can potentially contribute to unraveling the 972 

sedimentary and tectonic evolution of the paleoplate, where those basins are 973 

deposited, thus providing another tool for the reconstruction of past continental 974 

configurations. 975
