ABSTRACT 17 

Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins in the São Francisco 18 

Craton are classified into three megasequences: Statherian, Calymmian–early 19 

Ectasian, and Stenian–early Tonian sequences. The location, depositional age, 20 

and provenance of these sequences are reflected in their detrital zircon U–Pb 21 

age distributions. A minimum of five detrital zircon age distributions are 22 

distinguishable: i) the Archean and Rhyacian distribution, which is restricted to 23 

the Calymmian interval at Chapada Diamantina; ii) the Rhyacian distribution, 24 

which occurs in the Statherian, Calymmian, and Stenian intervals and generally 25 

precedes the Proterozoic distribution; iii) the Proterozoic distribution, which 26 

always succeeds the Rhyacian distribution and appears in the Brasília Belt and 27 

Southern Espinhaço; iv) the mixed Archean and Proterozoic distribution, 28 

restricted to the Stenian interval at the Southern Brasília Belt; and v) the 29 

Statherian distribution, which is present in the Statherian interval at Espinhaço 30

Basin and is recycled into the Calymmian and Stenian intervals at Chapada 31 

Diamantina. Based on the Hf isotope compositions of the detrital zircons, most 32 

of the sequences are predominantly sourced from Archean juvenile terrains and 33 

from Archean and Paleoproterozoic evolved terrains. The exception is the 34 

Paranoá Group, western São Francisco Craton, whose positive ?Hf(t) values 35 

suggest juvenile Paleoproterozoic sources such as the Goiás Massif. The 36 

Archean zircons from Chapada Diamantina have Hf depleted mantle model 37 

ages ranging from Paleoarchean to Neoarchean and are mainly derived from 38 

the Gavião Block within northeastern São Francisco Craton. The model unify a 39 

dataset spanning hundreds of millions of years of the depositional record over a 40 

large area of central and eastern Brazil. The records will assist researchers in 41 

unraveling the sedimentary and tectonic history of the Archean and 42 

Paleoproterozoic continents from new data collected regionally and in other 43 

continents. 44

KEYWORDS 46 

Detrital zircon; U-Pb; Lu-Hf; São Francisco Craton; Cratonic basins; 47 

Mesoproterozoic Era 48

1. INTRODUCTION 50 

 The composite Congo–São Francisco  Craton (Trompette et al., 1992; 51 

Alkmim et al., 2001) is one of the cratonic segments used for reconstructing the 52 

supercontinents from the Paleoproterozoic to Eopaleozoic Eras (Fig. 1 inset). 53 

Supercontinent reconstruction in these eras is contentious due to the scarcity of 54 

kinematic data. Working hypotheses have linked the Congo–São Francisco  55 

Craton to the Kahalari, Kaapval, and Rio de la Plata cratons; to other 56 

Precambrian cratons such as Siberia, Amazonian, West Africa, and to Laurentia 57 

and Baltica. These reconstructions imply the existence of different 58 

supercontinent masses, such as Atlantica, Columbia, and Nuna, which are 59 

mutually exclusive (e.g., Kröner and Cordani, 2003; Li et al., 2008; Evans, 2009; 60 

Pisarevsky et al., 2014). Moreover, the intracratonic depositional record of the 61 

older cratons, such as the Congo–São Francisco  Craton, stores the detrital 62

materials of its underlying continental crust and provides crucial information 63 

about the paleogeographic and tectonic evolution of supercontinents. 64 

 The Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins of the São 65 

Francisco Craton are exposed, either at their interiors or at the craton margins, 66 

where they have been deformed by external compressional belts of 67 

Neoproterozoic age (Figs. 1, 2). The crystalline basement of these basins are 68 

encompassed by Archean tonalite–trondhjemite–granodiorite suites (TTG) and 69 

Archean–Paleoproterozoic Greenstone belt terrains assembled during the 70 

Transamazonian–Eburnean orogenies in the Paleoproterozoic Era from ca. 2.2 71 

to 1.9 Ga (e.g., Ledru et al., 1994; Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). Following the 72 

collisional tectonics, the lithosphere of the proto-Congo–São Francisco  Craton 73 

was supposedly stretched as intracontinental rift basins formed from ca. 1.8 to 74 

1.68 Ga. These rift basins were succeeded by cratonic basins, in which 75 

unconformity bounded sequences were deposited between 1.6 and 0.9 Ga 76 

(e.g., Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Ribeiro et al., 77 

2013). 78 

 The evolution of Precambrian and Phanerozoic cratonic basins is 79 

incompletely understood (e.g., Roberts and Bally, 2012). In contrast to the 80 

Precambrian basins, the Phanerozoic cratonic basins have attracted much 81 

interest for their rich fossil fuels, most preserved stratigraphic record, and 82 

abundant fossiliferous successions. The lack of fossiliferous successions in the 83 

Precambrian cratonic basins has prevented biostratigraphic correlations. 84 

However, these basins present rather similar lithologic associations from which 85 

researchers have performed traditional lithostratigraphic correlations (local to 86 

regional). Other researchers have employed sequence stratigraphic concepts to 87 

correlate the key stratigraphic surfaces. On the other hand, because of 88 

difficulties in dating the deposition (and especially the unconformities), the strata 89 

in Precambrian cratonic basins cannot be easily chrono-correlated (Eriksson et 90 

al., 2001). 91 

 Provenance analysis has greatly benefitted from combined U–Pb and 92 

Lu–Hf analysis of detrital zircon grains by the laser ablation inductively coupled 93 

plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICPMS) technique. By virtue of its rapid data 94 

acquisition rate, LA-ICPMS analyzes a large number of detrital zircons. From 95

the U–Pb ages and the Hf isotopic compositions of detrital grains, we can infer 96 

the maximum depositional ages of sedimentary sequences and gather 97 

provenance information such as the ages and the petrogenetic constraints of 98 

granitic terrains in the source areas, the sedimentary recycling processes, the 99 

paleodrainage dispersion, and the provenance evolution through time (e.g., 100 

Nelson, 2001; Dickinson and Gehrels, 2009; Andersen 2014; Gehrels, 2014). 101 

The methodology is comprehensively reviewed in Gehrels (2014). Within the 102 

past two decades, hundreds of thousands of detrital zircon analyses have been 103 

conducted, improving our knowledge of the tectonic evolution of both sources 104 

and sinks. From isotopic analysis of detrital grains, we can also elucidate the 105 

provenance ages, petrogenesis, and maximum depositional ages of the cratonic 106 

basins in the São Francisco Craton (Valeriano et al., 2004; Valladares et al., 107 

2004; Marques, 2009; Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Matteini et al., 2012; Chaves et 108 

al., 2013; Ribeiro et al., 2013; Santos et al., 2013; Franz et al., 2014; 109 

Guadagnin, 2014; Danderfer et al., in press; Guadagnin et al., in press;). 110 

 The present paper compiles published and new detrital zircon U–Pb ages 111 

and Lu–Hf isotopes from the cratonic basins. The objective is to evaluate (1) the 112 

temporal and paleogeographic variations in the detrital zircon age distributions, 113 

(2) the maximum depositional ages of the cratonic sequences, (3) the potential 114 

source areas of the studied basins, and (4) the petrogenetic evolution of the 115 

source rocks. In addition, we discuss the implications of these information to the 116 

tectonic and sedimentary evolution of the São Francisco Craton from ca. 1.8 to 117 

0.9 Ga. 118

2. Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic Tectonostratigraphic 122 

Megasequences of the São Francisco Craton 123 

 The interior and margins of the São Francisco Craton expose a number 124 

of Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins with similar lithologic 125 

assemblages and stratigraphic frameworks. For decades, these basins were 126 

postulated to be chrono-correlated and their main developmental stages linked 127

to regional or global tectonic processes. Locally, each basin has been formally 128 

or informally subdivided based on lithostratigraphic, sequence, and/or 129 

allostratigraphic hierarchy. Meanwhile, the basinal evolution of the craton in 130 

response to local and global tectonic processes has been largely neglected. 131 

Broadly, the sedimentary record of the Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic 132 

cratonic basins began with the deposition of continental systems associated 133 

with mafic and/or felsic alkaline magmatism, dated between ca. 1.8 and 1.68 134 

Ga. These sequences are often attributed to the fill of a rift basin. After the main 135 

stage of rifting and bounded by regional unconformities, one or more cratonic 136 

tectonostratigraphic megasequences (TSM) were deposited. Conversely, some 137 

authors suggest the development of several rift stages. The minimum 138 

depositional age of the cratonic TSMs in the São Francisco Craton is defined by 139 

the intrusion of mafic dike swarms of ca. 0.9 Ga (Abreu, 1991; Loureiro et al., 140 

2008; Danderfer et al., 2009), which marked the development of a rifted 141 

continental margin in the São Francisco Craton with deposition of the 142 

Neoproterozoic sequences (e.g., Valladares et al., 2004; Babinski et al., 2012). 143 

 During the accretion of the Gondwana supercontinent in the 144 

Neoproterozoic Era, the Congo–São Francisco Craton collided with the 145 

surrounding cratons. These collisions variably deformed the cratonic sequences 146 

at the margins and interior of the craton. Consequently, some basins were 147 

disrupted and subsequent processes lead to the exposed present-day geology 148 

(Fig. 1). The seismic reflection profiles showed that the cratonic basins were 149 

continuous across the craton and overburdened by Neoproterozoic to 150 

Phanerozoic sequences (the São Francisco and Sanfranciscana basins; Fig 2; 151 

e.g., Campos and Dardenne, 1997). The Neoproterozoic deformation was 152 

higher at the margins and variable in the craton interior (Chemale Jr. et al., 153 

1993; Alkmim et al., 1996). 154 

 The following sections overview the available stratigraphic data of the 155 

Espinhaço Basin (Paramirim Aulacogen and eastern margin), the São João del 156 

Rey (southern margin), and the Araí and Paranoá basins (western margin). 157

2.1 Espinhaço Basin 161 

 The Espinhaço Basin (Espinhaço Supergroup) outcrops in three main 162 

geographic regions locally known as Serra do Espinhaço Meridional (the 163 

Southern Espinhaço range), Serra do Espinhaço Setentrional (the Northern 164 

Espinhaço range) and Chapada Diamantina (Diamantina Plateau; Fig. 1). The 165 

first occurs at the São Francisco Craton margin whereas the latter two occur at 166 

the Paramirim Aulacogen (sensu Cruz and Alkmim, 2006). The depositional 167 

environments and stratigraphy of the Espinhaço Supergroup in these three 168 

geographic regions has been extensively reported (e.g., Plug, 1968; Schöll and 169 

Fogaça, 1979; Dossin et al., 1990; Pedreira, 1994; Schobbenhaus, 1996; 170 

Danderfer and Dardenne, 2002). Recently, three megasequences have been 171 

recognized in the Espinhaço Basin record: the Lower (1.8–1.68 Ga), Middle 172 

(1.6–1.38 Ga), and Upper Espinhaço sequences (1.2–0.9 Ga). These 173 

megasequences were derived from relative and numeric age constraints 174 

available from structural, petrologic, stratigraphic, and geochronological studies 175 

(Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013; Guadagnin et al., in press).  176 

 177 

FIGURE 3 178 

 179 

 The basement of the proto-Congo–São Francisco Craton was 180 

consolidated ca. 2.0 Ga (Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). The geological record of 181 

the São Francisco Craton from ca. 2.0 to 1.8 Ga is limited; thereafter, an 182 

intraplate extensional process initiated the Lower Espinhaço megasequence 183 

(deposited between ca. 1.8 and 1.68 Ga), which is exposed at Chapada 184 

Diamantina and in the Southern and Northern Espinhaço ranges. 185 

 The Lower Espinhaço sequence at Chapada Diamantina comprises the 186 

Rio dos Remédios Group, which is encompassed by continental deposits of 187 

Serra da Gameleira Formation succeeded by volcanic rocks of Novo Horizonte 188 

Formation, dated at 1752 ± 4 Ma and 1748 ± 4 Ma (Schobbenhaus et al., 1994; 189 

Babinski et al., 1999; Fig. 3). The sequence ends with alluvial, eolian, and 190 

lacustrine deposits of Lagoa de Dentro and Ouricuri do Ouro Formations 191

(Guimarães et al., 2005; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; Guadagnin et al., in 192 

press). The magmatism of the Novo Horizonte Formation is coeval with that of 193 

Lagoa Real alkaline–peralkaline pluton, which is exposed south to southwest of 194 

Chapada Diamantina (within the Paramirim Aulacogen) and  formed at 1724 ± 5 195 

Ma (Turpin et al., 1988). In the Northern Espinhaço range, the Lower Espinhaço 196 

sequence is similar to that of the Chapada Diamantina and contains the 197 

continental deposits of the Algodão and Sapiranga Formations, which are 198 

interlayered with volcanic rocks dated at 1775 ± 3 Ma, 1740 ± 10 Ma, and 1731 199 

± 5 Ma (Danderfer et al., 2009, in press; Fig. 3). The Lower Espinhaço 200 

sequence in the Southern Espinhaço range comprises the continental deposits 201 

of the Bandeirinha Formation, which is succeeded by the basal portion of the 202 

Diamantina Group (São João da Chapada Formation). The São João da 203 

Chapada Formation is interlayered with Conceição do Mato Dentro rhyolite, 204 

dated at 1715 ± 2 Ma and 1710 ± 10 Ma (Brito Neves et al., 1979; Abreu, 1991; 205 

Fig. 3), and intruded by SiO2-undersaturated and highly K-alkaline hematite–206 

phyllite, dated at 1710 ± 12 Ma and 1703 ± 12 Ma (Dussin, 1994; Chemale Jr. 207 

et al., 2012). The maximum depositional ages of the Bandeirinha and São João 208 

da Chapada Formations are 1737 ± 11 Ma and 1683 ± 11 Ma, respectively 209 

(Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013). The magmatism of the Lower 210 

Espinhaço sequence in the Southern Espinhaço range is coeval to that of the 211 

1.75–1.67 Ga granites of the Borrachudos Suite (Brito Neves et al., 1979; 212 

Machado et al., 1989; Abreu, 1991; Dussin, 1994; Dussin and Dussin, 1995; 213 

Chemale Jr. et al., 1988) and the mafic dykes dated at 1715 ± 5 Ma (Silva et al., 214 

1995). 215 

 The Middle Espinhaço sequence is exposed only in the Northern 216 

Espinhaço range and at Chapada Diamantina (Fig. 3). The latter location 217 

comprises the Paraguaçú Group, consisting of the Mangabeira and Açuruá 218 

Formations (Pedreira, 1994; Guimarães et al., 2005), and the Tombador 219 

Formation (basal portion of the Chapada Diamantina Group; Guadagnin et al., 220 

in press). The Mangabeira Formation consists of alluvial and eolian deposits 221 

intruded by sills and dykes dated at 1514 ± 22 Ma and 1501 ± 9 Ma (Babinski et 222 

al., 1999; Silveira et al., 2013). The Mangabeira Formation is gradually 223 

succeeded by the Açuruá Formation, which comprises deltaic to shallow marine 224

deposits (Guimarães et al., 2005). The Açuruá is separated from the 225 

succeeding Tombador Formation by a well-documented angular unconformity 226 

associated with abrupt changes in sedimentary facies and paleocurrents 227 

(Pedreira, 1994; Guimarães et al., 2005; Loureiro et al., 2008; Pedreira and De 228 

Waele, 2008). The Tombador Formation is composed of marine, transitional, 229 

and continental deposits intercalated with thin volcaniclastic sandstone and 230 

conglomerate beds deposited at 1436 ± 26 Ma (Guadagnin et al., in press). In 231 

the Northern Espinhaço range, the Middle Espinhaço sequence comprises the 232 

Pajeú Group and the Bom Retiro Formation of Danderfer and Dardenne (2002; 233 

Fig. 3). The Bomba Formation volcanism, dated at 1582 ± 8 Ma and 1569 ± 14 234 

Ma (Danderfer et al., 2009), is a prominent geochronological marker defining 235 

the minimum depositional age of the Pajeú Group and the maximum 236 

depositional age of the Bom Retiro Formation. Unlike the Middle Espinhaço 237 

sequence, which is not preserved in the Southern Espinhaço range, the Upper 238 

Espinhaço sequence is well preserved and exposed in all three regions, 239 

although the Southern Espinhaço range admits the tightest numerical age 240 

control. 241 

 At Chapada Diamantina, the Upper Espinhaço sequence comprises the 242 

upper portions of Chapada Diamantina Group encompassed by marine deposits 243 

of the Caboclo Formation and continental deposits of the Morro do Chapéu 244 

Formation (Fig. 3; Pedreira, 1994; Pedreira and De Waele, 2008). The 245 

maximum depositional age of the Caboclo Formation is 1415 ± 41 Ma, whereas 246 

the carbonates were deposited at 1140 ± 140 Ma (whole-rock Pb–Pb isochron; 247 

Babinski et al., 1993). The Morro do Chapéu Formation constitutes the alluvial 248 

fill of incised valleys during aggradation following a degradational stage 249 

(Pedreira and De Waele, 2008). In the Northern Espinhaço range, the Upper 250 

Espinhaço sequence comprises coastal to marine deposits of the Riacho do 251 

Bento, Mosquito, and Fazendinha Formations within the São Marcos Group of 252 

Danderfer and Dardenne (2002). The unconformity above the São Marcos 253 

Group is succeeded by the Veredas (or Serra das Veredas), Viramundo, and 254 

Garapa Formations within the Sítio Novo Group (Danderfer and Dardenne, 255 

2002). Whether the Veredas Formation is cut by the ca. 0.9 Ga mafic dykes 256 

remains contentious. Intrusion by these dykes marks the end of the Espinhaço 257

Supergroup deposition (Schobbenhaus, 1996; Danderfer and Dardenne, 2002; 258 

Danderfer et al., 2009; Franz et al., 2014). The maximum depositional age for 259 

the Veredas Formation is 1514 ± 14 Ma (maximum depositional age; Franz et 260 

al., 2014). In the Southern Espinhaço range, the Upper Espinhaço sequence 261 

has been identified by detrital zircon age analyses. The depositional age of the 262 

Sopa–Brumadinho Formation was deduced from ca. 1.2 Ga volcanic zircon 263 

grains found in this unit (Fig. 3; Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013). 264 

The stratigraphic intervals deposited above the Sopa–Brumadinho Formation, 265 

encompassed by the Galho do Miguel Formation and Conselheiro Mata Group, 266 

are younger than 1.2 Ga. The youngest detrital zircon grains from Conselheiro 267 

Mata Group sandstones are dated at 1417 ± 22 Ma (Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; 268 

Santos et al., 2013). 269 

 The minimum age of the Espinhaço Supergroup deposition was defined 270 

from the mafic dyke swarms that intruded the proto-Congo–São Francisco  271 

Craton between 0.95 and 0.90 Ga (Abreu, 1991; Loureiro et al., 2008; 272 

Danderfer et al., 2009; Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Ernst et al., 2013). 273 

 274 

2.2 São Francisco Craton southern margin 275 

 The southern margin of the craton (Fig. 1) contains the southern 276 

Neoproterozoic Brasília Belt, a complex mosaic of thrust sheets resulting from 277 

the accretion of the Gondwana supercontinent in the Neoproterozoic Era. This 278 

complex structure precludes any lithostratigraphic correlations between the 279 

internal/allochthonous, external/autochthonous, and cratonic domains and 280 

between the southern and northern Brasília Belt (e.g., Valeriano et al., 2004). 281 

The Mesoproterozoic strata include the São João del Rey and Carandaí basins 282 

in the cratonic domain (Ribeiro et al., 2013) and the Andrelândia Basin in the 283 

internal and external domains (Valeriano et al., 2004). 284 

 The São João del Rey Basin consists of the Tiradentes Formation, which 285 

comprises the Tiradentes, São José, Tejuco, and Lenheiro sequences (Ribeiro 286 

et al., 2013). The São João del Rey Basin extends to 1 km of shallow-water 287 

marine and coastal siliciclastic rocks deposited in the cratonic domain (Ribeiro 288 

et al., 2013). The maximum depositional age for the São João del Rey Basin is 289

1539 ± 11 Ma, whereas its minimum depositional age is poorly constrained by 290 

the TDM (Nd) model ages (ca. 1.4 Ga) of the mafic dykes cutting the Tiradentes 291 

Formation (Ribeiro et al., 2013). However, the São João del Rey Basin is 292 

indisputably younger than the Carandaí Basin (Fig. 4; Ribeiro et al., 2013). 293 

 The Carandaí Basin comprises the Carandaí, Barroso, and Prados 294 

Formations, each formed in a different context (Ribeiro et al., 2013). The 295 

Carandaí Formation is composed of diamictites of local provenance deposited 296 

after 1412 ± 23 Ma, the Barroso Formation consists of carbonate sequences 297 

deposited in a sag basin, and the Prados Formation corresponds to the pelitic 298 

strata deposited in a fault-bounded basin with a maximum depositional age of 299 

1186 ± 11 Ma. (Ribeiro et al., 2013). The Andrelândia Basin was deposited in 300 

the rifted continental margin of the craton and records the development of a 301 

passive margin basin with a maximum depositional age of 1061 ± 45 Ma (Fig. 4; 302 

Valeriano et al., 2004; Valladares et al., 2004). During the Gondwana 303 

supercontinent assembly, the Neoproterozoic collision variably deformed the 304 

Andrelândia Basin. 305 

 306 

2.3 São Francisco Craton western margin 307 

 In the western margin of the craton (northern Brasília Belt), the 308 

Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic basins are encompassed by the Araí, 309 

Serra da Mesa, and Paranoá Groups (Fig. 1;Pimentel et al., 1991; Marques, 310 

2009; Matteini et al., 2012). In the Araí Group, deposition was initiated in a rift 311 

basin filled by continental deposits of the Arraias Formation. The siliciclastic 312 

sediments are interlayered with mafic to felsic volcanic rocks whose U–Pb age 313 

(1771 ± 2 Ma) defines the depositional age of the Araí Group (Fig. 4; Pimentel 314 

et al., 1991). The volcanism was coeval with that of tin-bearing granites (ca. 315 

1.77 Ga; Pimentel et al., 1991, 1999). The rift stage was succeeded by a 316 

flexural stage, marked by a depositional transition to marine deposits of the 317 

Traíras Formation (Marques, 2009; Tanizaki, 2013). 318 

 The Serra da Mesa Group corresponds to a succession of 319 

quartzites/metapelites, probably deposited in a marine setting. The maximum 320 

depositional age of the Serra da Mesa Group is 1557 ± 24 Ma (Marques, 2009). 321

The structural relations between the Araí and Serra da Mesa Groups and the 322 

Serra da Mesa and related granites are currently debated. Serra da Mesa 323 

Granite is described either as the basement or intruding the Araí and Serra da 324 

Mesa Groups (Marini and Botelho, 1986; Pimentel et al., 1991; Dardenne et al., 325 

2003). The zircon ages of the Serra da Mesa Granite are somewhat imprecise 326 

but lie between 1.57 and 1.61 Ga (Pimentel et al., 1991; Rossi et al., 1992), 327 

overlapping the maximum depositional age of the Serra da Mesa Group 328 

(Marques, 2009). This overlap permits two interpretations. In one scenario, the 329 

Serra da Mesa Granite formed the basement of the Serra da Mesa Group, the 330 

youngest zircon grains within the Serra da Mesa Group sandstones were 331 

derived from the coeval granites, and the minimum depositional age is marked 332 

by the unconformity with the Paranoá Group. Alternatively, the Serra da Mesa 333 

Granite intruded the Serra da Mesa and Araí Groups, and granite positioning 334 

occurred shortly after the deposition of the Serra da Mesa Group. 335 

 The Paranoá Group encompasses the shallow-water marine siliciclastic 336 

deposits that unconformably overlie the Araí Group (Alvarenga et al., 2012, 337 

2014 and references therein). The youngest detrital zircon age cluster 338 

(maximum depositional age) in the Paranoá Group is 1560 ± 10 Ma (Matteini et 339 

al., 2012). However, the Paranoá Group contains Conophyton metulum 340 

Kirichenkio (stromatolite) and microfossils (Dardenne et al., 1976; Fairchild et 341 

al., 1996), indicating a depositional age younger than 1.2 Ga (Fig. 4; Alvarenga 342 

et al., 2014). Deposition conclusion in the Paranoá Group is defined by 343 

diagenetic xenotime overgrowths in detrital zircons, aged at 1042 ± 22 Ma 344 

(Matteini et al., 2012). The stratigraphic framework (litho-, allo-, or sequence 345 

stratigraphy) of the Paranoá Group has been informally defined in several 346 

locations by different methods and units of subdivision. The Paranoá Group is 347 

subdivided into five, nine, or twelve stratigraphic successions that expose 348 

coastal to marine deposits (Alvarenga et al., 2012; Campos et al., 2013 and 349 

references therein). The deposition occurred at the western margin of the São 350 

Francisco Craton, possibly within a passive margin basin close to an ocean 351 

crust (ca. 1.25 Ga; Palmeirópolis, Indianópolis, and Juscelândia meta-volcano-352 

sedimentary sequences; Delgado et al., 2003; Pimentel et al., 2000, 2011; 353 

Matteini et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2012; Campos et al., 2013). The Paranoá 354

and Lu–Hf isotopes (if available) from the above-described cratonic basins (the 363 

data sources are provided in Table S1). The compilation includes U–Pb ages 364 

within 100 ± 10% of concordance. To determine the age groups (clusters) in the 365 

detrital zircon age data, the Pb

 Figures 5–9 are normalized probability density plots (NPDPs) of the U–376 

Pb ages from each stratigraphic unit. Below, we detail the detrital zircon age 377 

distribution in the Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins, 378 

beginning with the Statherian interval, progressing to the Calymmian–early 379 

Ectasian interval, and concluding with the Stenian–early Tonian interval. These 380 

intervals are correlated with the Lower, Middle, and Upper Espinhaço 381 

sequences, respectively (Fig. 4; Chemale Jr. et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2013; 382 

Guadagnin et al., in press). 383

4. Discussion 517 

 The above compilation demonstrates the variability of the detrital zircon 518 

U–Pb ages in the Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins. At least 519 

five distinct detrital zircon age distributions are distinguishable in these basins, 520 

depending on the depositional age and geographic locations of the basins 521 

relative to the São Francisco Craton. 522 

 1. The Archean and Rhyacian distribution (ArPP; Fig. 8) is a multimodal 523 

age distribution comprising distinct Paleoarchean (3.6–3.2 Ga), Neoarchean 524 

(2.8–2.5 Ga), and Rhyacian (2.3–2.05 Ga) ages and variable quantities of 525 

Statherian (1.8–1.6 Ga) and Calymmian ages (1.6–1.4 Ga). The ArPP is 526 

restricted to the Calymmian–early Ectasian sequence at the Chapada 527 

Diamantina Basin (Açuruá and Tombador Formations). 528 

 2. The Rhyacian age distribution (RHY, aged 2.3–2.05 Ga; Figs. 5–9) 529 

also includes variable quantities of Archean, Siderian (2.5–2.3 Ga), Statherian, 530 

and Calymmian ages, depending on depositional age and location. RHY is the 531 

most frequent age distribution and is found in the Statherian, Calymmian–early 532 

Ectasian, and Stenian–early Tonian sequences of the cratonic basins. RHY is 533 

present in the Statherian sequence at the Northern Espinhaço (Algodão 534 

Formation), Southern Espinhaço (São João da Chapada Formation), and Araí 535 

basins. RHY also appears in the Calymmian–early Ectasian sequence at the 536 

Chapada Diamantina (Mangabeira Formation) and São João Del Rey basins 537 

(Tiradentes Formation), and in the Stenian–early Tonian sequence at the 538 

Northern Espinhaço (Veredas Formation), Southern Espinhaço (Sopa–539 

Brumadinho and Galho do Miguel Formations), and Paranoá basins (Paranoá 540 

Group). 541 

 3. The Paleoproterozoic and Mesoproterozoic distribution (PMP; Figs. 6, 542 

7, and 9) is predominantly Orosirian (2.05–1.8 Ga) with variable quantities of 543 

Rhyacian and Statherian ages, minor quantities of Calymmian ages, and no 544 

Archean ages. PMP is present in the Calymmian–early Ectasian sequence at 545

 4. The mixed Archean and Proterozoic distribution (MAP; Fig. 9) is a 548 

multimodal age distribution including variable quantities of Neoarchean, 549 

Rhyacian, Orosirian, Statherian, Calymmian, Ectasian (1.4–1.2 Ga), and 550 

Stenian (1.2–1.0 Ga) ages. MAP is restricted to the Stenian–early Tonian 551 

sequence at the Andrelândia Basin (Prados Formation and Andrelândia Group). 552 

 5. The Statherian distribution (STT; Figs. 5, 6, and 8) is defined by a 553 

dominant Statherian age distribution, with variable quantities of Neoarchean, 554 

Siderian (2.5–2.3 Ga), Rhyacian, and Calymmian ages, depending on 555 

depositional age and location. STT is present in the Statherian sequence at the 556 

Northern and Southern Espinhaço basins (Sapiranga and Bandeirinha 557 

Formations respectively), and in the Stenian–early Tonian sequence at the 558 

Chapada Diamantina Basin (Caboclo Formation). The NPDPs for the five zircon 559 

age distributions are presented in Figure 10. 560

FIGURE 10 562 

  563 

 Each zircon age peak correlates to a known source within the São 564 

Francisco Craton. The Eoarchean to Paleoarchean zircons are related to the 565 

first crustal assemblages of the tonalite–trondhjemite–granodiorite suites (TTG) 566 

and greenstone belts that were reworked in the Neoarchean and 567 

Paleoproterozoic Eras (Rhyacian Period; Barbosa and Sabaté, 2004). The 568 

Neoarchean and Paleoproterozoic grains derive from either juvenile material or 569 

Paleoarchean reworked material. The Archean and Rhyacian ages are related 570 

to basement rocks within the São Francisco Craton. Specifically, the Rhyacian 571 

ages are related to Paleoproterozoic rocks formed during the 572 

Transamazonian/Eburnean orogenic cycle, when the Congo–São Francisco 573 

Craton assembled. All zircon grains older than 1.8 Ga are stored in the 574 

Espinhaço Supergroup at different proportions, depending on stratigraphic level 575 

and geographic distribution, and were either sourced from a first-order sediment 576 

derived from a nearby basement or subjected to successive cycles of 577

 The U–Pb age distributions of the detrital zircons from Chapada 581 

Diamantina are mainly assignable to Paleoarchean, Neoarchean, and Rhyacian 582 

ages, and secondarily to Statherian and Calymmian ages. In the remaining 583 

locations, Rhyacian is the most frequent detrital zircon age distribution, followed 584 

by Statherian. Minor distributions of Neoarchean and Calymmian ages are 585 

found in the Southern and Northern Espinhaço ranges; and Statherian, 586 

Calymmian, and a few Archean ages appear in the Northern Brasília Belt. The 587 

Southern Brasília Belt is exceptional because it presents Stenian ages, as well 588 

as Rhyacian, Statherian, Calymmian, and Neoarchean ages. 589 

 In the following section, we relate the U–Pb detrital zircon age 590 

distributions to the sedimentary evolution of the Paleoproterozoic to 591 

Mesoproterozoic cratonic megasequences of the São Francisco Craton.  592 

  593 

4.1 Lower Megasequence (Statherian Interval) 594 

 The detrital zircon age distributions of the Lower megasequence are very 595 

similar in the Southern and Northern Espinhaço ranges, and embrace 596 

Statherian and Rhyacian ages. The Statherian units (Araí Group) in the 597 

Northern Brasília Belt present only the Rhyacian distribution. These patterns 598 

suggest that the detrital materials that filled the Statherian rift basins were 599 

derived from the erosion of Transamazonian/Eburnean orogenic units, 600 

themselves formed during amalgamation of the Congo–São Francisco  601 

paleoplate, and also from magmatic activity coeval with basin deposition (Fig. 602 

10). The widespread Rhyacian age distribution in the Statherian sequences, 603 

found in the Algodão, Araí, and São João da Chapada Formations, indicate that 604 

these units derived from the denudation of Transamazonian/Eburnean sources. 605 

Although zircons older than ca. 1.8 Ga are presumably derived from basement 606 

units, zircons aged 1.78–1.7 Ga make an important contribution to the 607 

Sapiranga and Bandeirinha Formations (Fig. 10). These zircon grains are 608

 611 

4.2 Middle Megasequence (Calymmian–early Ectasian Interval) 612 

 The detrital zircon age distributions in the Calymmian–early Ectasian 613 

interval depended on the basin location. In the Chapada Diamantina, the age 614 

distribution was predominantly Rhyacian in the Mangabeira Formation and 615 

Archean and Rhyacian in the Açuruá and lower Tombador Formations (Fig. 10). 616 

This source area change is attributable to stratigraphic inversion in the source 617 

area. The older stratigraphic units (the Mangabeira Formation) record the 618 

detrital material derived from the youngest units in the São Francisco Craton 619 

basement, while the younger stratigraphic units (the Açuruá and lower 620 

Tombador Formations) record the denudation of the oldest units within the 621 

Gavião Block of the São Francisco Craton basement (Barbosa and Sabaté, 622 

2004; Fig. 10). Also within the Chapada Diamantina, Statherian and Calymmian 623 

aged material were deposited between the lower and upper Tombador 624 

Formation by uplift and exposition of the Statherian sequences, leading to a 625 

sedimentary recycling process and addition of synsedimentary volcanic material 626 

(Calymmian ages).  627 

 The zircon age distributions in the Northern and Southern Brasília Belts 628 

differ from those in the Chapada Diamantina. The Northern Brasília Belt include 629 

the Serra da Mesa Group, part of the Calymmian–early Ectasian 630 

megasequence (Fig. 4), whose Proterozoic age distribution differs from the 631 

Statherian units of the Araí Group (Fig. 10). In the Southern Brasília Belt, the 632 

Calymmian–early Ectasian units are represented by Tiradentes and Carandaí 633 

Formations, each with distinct detrital zircon age distributions (Rhyacian in the 634 

Tiradentes Formation; Proterozoic in the Carandaí Formation). The presence of 635 

a major Orosirian peak in the Proterozoic distribution is intriguing, because this 636 

age is uncommon in the basement of the São Francisco Craton and its 637 

surrounding areas. The Rhyacian and subordinate Archean and Statherian 638 

distributions are attributable to either basement contributions or sedimentary 639 

recycling. The Calymmian zircons were derived from coeval magmatic activity in 640 

the Serra da Mesa and Carandaí Formations. 641

 Based on the U–Pb ages and Hf isotope compositions of the same 642 

detrital zircon grains from the Middle and Upper Espinhaço sequences in the 643 

Chapada Diamantina, we infer that the crustal sources were dominated by 644 

Paleoarchean and Neoarchean, with subordinate juvenile contribution (Fig. 11). 645 

Despite occurring as the subordinate material, the ages and Hf isotope 646 

compositions of the Statherian and Calymmian zircon grains indicate their 647 

relation to mixed Paleoproterozoic and Mesoproterozoic crustal sources. 648 

Archean crustal contribution is rare in this region. Therefore, during the 649 

Calymmian–early Ectasian Periods, the Chapada Diamantina region received 650 

detrital materials from Archean terrains differently from the other stratigraphic 651 

units in the Northern and Southern Brasília Belts, which present minor Archean 652 

age distributions. 653

4.3 Upper Megasequence (Stenian–early Tonian Interval) 656 

 The zircon age distribution varies in the Stenian–early Tonian sequence 657 

of the cratonic basins. At Chapada Diamantina, a Statherian age distribution 658 

predominates in the Caboclo Formation, indicating recycling of the Calymmian 659 

sequences (upper Tombador Formation). In the Southern Espinhaço range, a 660 

Rhyacian age distribution dominates the diamond-bearing alluvial deposits of 661 

Sopa–Brumadinho Formation and the coastal eolian and marine deposits of the 662 

Galho do Miguel Formation (Fig. 10). This age distribution relates either to the 663 

denudation of Transamazonian/Eburnean sources or recycling from lower 664 

sequences. Notably, the Sopa–Brumadinho Formation includes tuff layers with 665 

juvenile volcanic Stenian zircon grains aged around 1.2 Ga, which define the 666 

depositional age of this sequence. Atop the cratonic basins in the Southern 667 

Espinhaço range in the Conselheiro Mata Group, the detrital zircon age 668 

distribution alters from Rhyacian to Proterozoic, consistent with denudation of 669 

basement sources and sedimentary recycling (Fig. 10). The zircons in the 670 

shallow-water marine units of the Conselheiro Mata Group are of Orosirian and 671 

Calymmian ages. The Calymmian grains are correlated with the erosion of the 672 

Middle Espinhaço megasequence, which is absent in the Southern Espinhaço 673 

range region. 674

 A Rhyacian age distribution dominates the age distribution in the 675 

Northern Brasilia Belt and is attributable to erosion of the 676 

Transamazonian/Eburnean or recycled terrains. The Paranoá Group, which is 677 

attributed to a passive margin basin fill (see Alvarenga et al., 2014 and 678 

references therein), correlates with the Upper Espinhaço megasequence to the 679 

East (Fig. 2) and presents a similar Rhyacian zircon age distribution (Fig. 10). 680 

The Hf isotopic compositions of the detrital zircons in the Paranoá Group reveal 681 

a large proportion of juvenile Paleoproterozoic grains, suggesting that this 682 

stratigraphic unit is mainly contributed by a western source within the large 683 

Goiás Massif or a similar terrain (Pimentel et al., 2000). However, the main 684 

Paleoproterozoic zircons of the Middle and Upper Espinhaço sequences in the 685 

Southern Espinhaço range and Chapada Diamantina are evolved zircons with 686 

crustal signature and dominant Archean sources. 687 

 South of the São Francisco Craton, the units present contrasting zircon 688 

age distributions. The Prados Formation and Andrelândia Group exclusively 689 

present a mixed Archean and Proterozoic age distribution including Calymmian, 690 

Ectasian, and Stenian zircon ages (Fig. 10). These ages are uncommon in the 691 

São Francisco Craton. They have been reported in scarce amounts in the 692 

Tombador Formation (Guadagnin et al., in press), the Sopa–Brumadinho 693 

Formation (Chemale Jr. et al., 2012), and in the Neoproterozoic Glacial deposits 694 

of Macaúbas and Jequitaí Groups (Babinski et al., 2012). The  mixed Archean 695 

and Proterozoic age distribution (with large amounts of Ectasian and Stenian 696 

ages) in the Upper megasequence of the Southern Brasília Belt suggests that 697 

these zircons were mainly sourced from the southern São Francisco Craton or a 698 

neighboring region and were rare in the Espinhaço domains to the north. 699 

 700 

5. Conclusions 701 

 The detrital zircon age distributions in the Paleoproterozoic to 702 

Mesoproterozoic cratonic megasequences of the São Francisco Craton depend 703 

on depositional age and geographic location. The zircon age distributions are 704 

controlled by the variable ages of the basement units, mediated by magmatism 705 

coeval with basin deposition and recycling processes. The Statherian (Lower), 706 

Calymmian–early Ectasian (Middle), and Stenian–early Tonian sequences 707

(Upper) yielded five main detrital zircon age distributions that function as 708 

fingerprints for determining these sequences in different geographic areas, 709 

namely (i) Archean and Rhyacian age distribution (ArPP), (ii) Rhyacian age 710 

distribution (RHY), (iii) Proterozoic age distribution (PMP), (iv) Mixed Archean 711 

and Proterozoic age distribution (MAP), and (v) Statherian age distribution 712 

(STT). 713 

 The Archean zircon populations, either juvenile or evolved (indicated by 714 

positive and negative ?Hf(t) values and Neoarchean to Paleoarchean depleted 715 

mantle Hf model ages), exist only in the northern portion of the São Francisco 716 

Craton in the Chapada Diamantina. In this region, the zircon populations are 717 

directly linked to the denudation of the Gavião Block, a Meosarchean to 718 

Paleoarchean crustal segment of the craton. 719 

 The most frequent U–Pb zircon age distribution is the Rhyacian age, 720 

which may be directly related to the denudation of Transamazonian/Eburnean 721 

units in the Statherian sequences and to recycling processes in the Calymmian 722 

and Stenian–early Tonian sequences. The Paranoá Group, encompassed in the 723 

Stenian sequence, presents a Rhyacian age distribution with numerous juvenile 724 

detrital zircons, likely sourced from granite-gneiss and volcano-sedimentary 725 

sequences within the Goiás Massif, located west of the São Francisco Craton. 726 

 The Proterozoic age distribution, which always succeeds the Rhyacian 727 

distribution, is attributed to denudation of basement sources with addition of 728 

Mesoproterozoic zircon grains. 729 

 The mixed Archean and Proterozoic age distribution containing 730 

significant amounts of Ectasian and Stenian zircons is restricted to the southern 731 

portion of the São Francisco Craton in the Stenian–early Tonian sequence. This 732 

age distribution suggests sedimentary recycling of zircons older than 1.2 Ga, 733 

with additional input of coeval magmatic material. 734 

 The Statherian age distribution appears in the Statherian and Stenian–735 

early Tonian sequences. In the Statherian sequence, this age distribution can 736 

be directly attributed to magmatism coeval with basin deposition, whereas in the 737 

Stenian–early Tonian sequence, it likely derives from uplift and exposition of the 738 

Statherian sequence. This latter process is restricted to Chapada Diamantina. 739 

 The data presented here span hundreds of millions of years of 740 

sedimentary record exposed over a large area of central-east Brazil. The results 741

Figure 1: Sketch map showing location of the Andrelândia, Araí, Carandaí, 1076 

Espinhaço, Paranoá, and São João del Rey basins at the interiors and craton 1077 

margins. The black lines indicate the most accepted extent of the São Francisco 1078 

Craton after ca. 540 Ma and the probable extent of the proto-craton at ca. 1.8 1079 

Ga. The 1.8 Ga proto-São Francisco Craton includes the Archean–1080 

Paleoproterozoic units partially reworked in the Neoproterozoic Era and the 1081 

Paleoproterozoic–Mesoproterozoic cratonic basins (e.g., Delgado et al., 2003; 1082 

Heilbron et al., 2010). The inset shows the situation in respect to SW 1083 

Gondwana supercontinent (modified from Unrug, 1992). I - Diamantina Plateau 1084 

(Chapada Diamantina), II - Northern Espinhaço range, III - Southern Espinhaço 1085 

range, IV - Southern Brasília Belt (São João del Rey, Carandaí, and 1086 

Andrelândia basins), V - Northern Brasília Belt (Araí, Serra da Mesa, and 1087 

Paranoá basins). The red line locates the seismic reflection profile of figure 2. 1088 

 1089 

Figure 2: Simplified interpreted seismic reflection profile (vertical scale is two-1090 

way travel time in seconds, TWT) along the southern portion of the São 1091 

Francisco Craton showing the three Paleoproteorozoic–Mesoproterozoic 1092 

cratonic megasequences, the Statherian, Calymmian–early Ectasian, and 1093 

Stenian–early Tonian sequences. Interpretation was based on published data in 1094 

Zalán and Romeiro-Silva (2007), Coelho et al. (2008), and Alvarenga et al. 1095 

(2012). The Stenian–early Tonian sequence includes the Paranoá sequence, 1096 

which crops-out in the western margin of the craton, and the Upper Espinhaço 1097 

sequence (sensu Chemale Jr. et al., 2012), exposed in the eastern margin. For 1098 

the profile location see Figure 1. 1099
